title: Rainy day in Maastricht
description: A full on weekend of African festival and trying to get things done: Buying boxes, cutting hair, watching DJ toothless (Rod). Meeting up with Michel and D. and getting drunk.

The day after, Claire's plane left her stranded in Amsterdam, so after much messing around she stayed with the ever mighty Karl. Next week looks like more juggling, sorting and one Vodafone party and one leaving do - mine.

Karl visiting at the weekend and my mum is over on Sunday. I leave for France a week on Tuesday or is it Wednesday, only to meet Claire the next day and then we calm down in the pool before we kiss goodbye to Europe and start the trip. Where?
Karl just opened another beer, is it a Duvel?

title: OK, why not
description: It was new year 2007, just after going through a great deal of pain trying to land a nice contract, that failed. Shouldn't work for fucking banks anyway. You see, we live in different countries and that is shit. The contract was gonna be a step to start in another city. It was half arsed attempt to do this, the bullshit involved is huge and I reckon would take at least a year to clear up.

So it was a crap new year and general crap time and it was against my idea, that this year should be easy. Last year was fucking great and so hectic. So we decided to travel. Pack our jobs in and get gone. No more bills, no more routine, no more job, no more house! Step off and let all that stuff come back in a years time. Initially we thought we could do this after we settled in a city for a year, this would make a great deal of sense financially, but also could mean that we wouldn't travel. It soon came clear it was now or never and even worse that that, we should have done it years ago!

I've got some friends that are gonna be in Bolivia in August, so this is our starting spot. So South America and then on to New Zealand, Thailand and then on to India, before returning back to Europe. First its jabs, visas and all that stuff and a better plan. We went to  and found a few things out. Like you can  only fly to New Zealand from Santiago (in Chile).

We looking at spending around GBP 1,900 on a round the world ticket and spending GBP 25 a day. So roughly, we got to get together GBP 10,000 and we are away. With our savings, we could do this by the summer (northern hemisphere). The timings of when to visit places is awkward also, it will be winter in Bolivia when we get there and snowy in Chile. Also it might be rainy season when we get to Thailand. There was a flood in Indonesia a couple of weeks ago displacing 100's of thousands of people, as this  can tell you. So there's a lot of planning to do. Also the Philippines looks good and Sri Lanka has this huge monument that has a wonderful view. You can dive with Sharks in the Maldives. Lots of options, too many. It should be great, thats if we don't fall out, get really sick, get robbed, go insaine. No fuck all that, its gonna be great

title: Overcast by the pool
description: Maastricht is history, as is my push bike. Rod was kind enough to take it off my hands. Went to see Harry on my last night and he gave me a book that is "all you need to know about South America"....
Everything fitted in the car and after a heroic 10 hours drive (not that I was driving) I'm now in France, as is Bear, we picked her up yesterday. Thank's to Mar and Peter!
We saw a few bands scattered around the town on the night of 21st before heading back for more wine and general knackedness.
Today, I have been let down by Vodafone by two grand and almost-accidentally inflicted an injury on Bear in the pool just before it rained.
It got better though, we fell into the pit that is Noz - ultra car boot sale shop and now we are drinking beer before going out for Chinese food.
We have insurance but no reply from Quito hotel emails. Erm.....

title: Saturday Hangover
description: Chinese was ok, but the  were great. Also  have replied, so all good in spite of the stratus greying the day and a bird trapped in the fire, that managed to be ushered out the door using the dark room and open bright door technique.

Went on a guided walk. Not much walking, a lot of French talking and a great deal of allotments,. I think it was some sort of gardeners walk. Although we did see flood lines carved into a bridge and graffiti from the 1917 and these....
Got recommended gypsy music gig and  by Canadian Czech. It was a gig too far so we just hit the booze and listened to music outside instead and a bit of Glastonbury TV.

title: Coastal timeslip
description: Chaos of the Quito bus station may have been made worse by the fact we where reading the time from a watch that wasn't good at telling it, and was in fact, wrong.
Got on the bus after much messing around and then on to 10 hour meandering trip through the Andes and through shanty town and the worst banana plantations in the world.

We get to Puerto Lopez in the middle of the night after many a bus station, where people get on the bus and try and sell you chicken and chips, coconut milk in plastic bags with ice cubes or a lemon to suck on or maybe a peach. All rubbish out the window.

So where's the taxi? There's a moterbike though. We walk across the dust road and get on the back seat, (which is a double seat) and we chug down the bumpy road to the paradise. We are meet by the swiz/italian couple who run the place. She offers us a sandwich, we take a beer. After which, we take a quick walk through the botanical gardens into our hut and crash.

The next couple of days we are kicking dead crabs over on the beach, getting twisted on cheap rum, watching the pterodactyls (frigates) and turkey vaulters in the sky. We swim in the pacific ocean, we get on a boat and see... blue footed boobies, albatrosses, whales (!), a whole load of fish underwater.
Tomorrow we get on another bus for a monster trip to Cuenca, but first here's a load of pictures...

title: From Beach to Birthday
description: Hot today! Been to Cuence - bit boring, although we got to meet the falling down frog in the shack that was the reptile and fish museum. I reckon that croc could have taken the whole place down. Saw Piranhas (most are veggie) and nasty snakes though.

On to Loja (J pronounced H) and then on to the small town of Vilcabamba. We find a place for a night, before heading up the hill to stay in a great hostel with a really wonderful panoramic view of the Andes.

My birthday we go into the cloud forest with a great Finnish couple. We get a bus out to the national park, get out and walked along the edge of the light gray mud road. Trees steeply went up at either side, I joked that the guide would tell us we had to just start climbing into the forest from here. Then he did.

Proper adventure into thick forest, although it was a route he did every day and he had a machete which at some stages he cleared the path a bit. It was a good route though, over rocks, under fallen trees and bits where the forest opened up to wonderful rolling views of trees covered in slow moving clouds. It was all good, tall trees with vines like rope and tick roots that help the tree shift direction, also huge ferns, well everything was exaggerated.

No animals though, although we did see puma tracks, not many birds either and no bugs apart from one scarab beetle, but well worth doing, although I write this on the 23rd and yes I still ache. See if you can spot the hummingbird nest in the pictures below.

That night we decided to got into town for booze and to celebrate my 36th year. This is where the weirdness begins. We find the most interesting looking bar that looks over the square where the local populaces drink shorts.

It didn't take long until the people on the next table (English, Irish and American) start talking to us. One bloke is from Belper. He's 32 and his favorite band growing up was Pitchshifter. He brought it up, its all too weird..... How far do you have to go? He's been out the country for about 10 years and knows Shib, Dig, the scum pups, Bivouac, etc, etc. Although we can't remember his name. Another bloke was with us from London, who was public school gay into licking frogs and could talk to Claire about Paganism.

Fueled on booze we go all over the village, this involves one bad jazz gig, two clubs, one at which the local police turned up at, even though the place was empty, nothing happens, although the Belper bloke, who has a very strong accent and has the front of a stereotypical Manc, says “Hold on lads the coppers here, get your 5 dollars ready”. We walk back up the hill to the hostel at 4 in the morning. Great day, the next was motionless.
Claire's now on, only one cup of tea a day! Here's the photos.....

title: Run around
description: Just waking up in Mindo. This a great place, hummingbirds by day, firefly at night. We spend yesterday morning hurtling across the canopy roof on a ten wire death slide. Nothing like dangling upside down over a huge drop to the tree filled valley floor to start your day. Apparently there are toucans and parrots here but they must be hiding.

We get the bus to Quito today to meet up with Jude, Rick and Debbie. Its about time we left as all the mozzies around here are just about as drunk as they can get after having a feast on Claire's legs.

There goes the cock running out side my cabin looking for some more hens to run at. We've been on horses, up volcano's, around the devils nose, all sorts of random stuff. Anyway here are some more photos and maybe a film.

title: Swimming up hill in eucalyptus sun
description: Back to Quito again stumble over Debbie in a bar. Soon after Ed and then Rick and Jude arrive after American faff. Before we knew it we where throwing ourselves around a hired jeep

We went up Pasachoa and watched a few eagles and condors. It gets cold up there but that was nothing next day was Pululahua and our first taste of snow and fog obscuring volcano views. Rick couldn't make this due to food poisoning at a dodgy Mexican.

Again the cold was really nothing, as the next day after helping a van out of the stream and our driver refusing to go any further, due to a recent jeep flip, we got out and put on more layers as the snow fell. We struggled up  (almost 5000 meters!) which was hell blizzard and made it to the refuged a bit frozen. No friendly fire waiting, just a scamming local, we soon descended and thawed out at a wonderful Guachai hacienda. We lit the fire in our rooms and took it easy for a while.

Next stop was the cosy spar town of Banos. We got straight into the thermal baths. The next day we absailed down some waterfalls. Truly scary, some of us neshed it. The biggest being 45 meters straight down, although total control, a beautiful experience. However, some evil insect manged to leave his spike in Claire at the bottom.
Back to the hostel for too much rum etc, broken chairs and telling off by neighbors, then up next morning for white water rafting for two hours down the Rio Negro.
After about our 10th meal at the brilliant hood cafe we headed back to Quito.. Here are some photos... Oh and Claire and I went to the center of the world....

title: Street money traders and graffiti on cacti
description: After the short sharp shock of Guayaquil we hit the small surf town of Montanita but the sun only shone for one day so we made do bouncing around in the waves. In retrospect maybe this was a good thing as Mick dived over a huge wave not realising it would be much shallower on the other side and grated his nose on the sand. (oops) Scabby nose for at least a week.

We finally arrived in  Paddington's homeland. We met our tour guide for the day who was called Marcelles or Octopus to his friends, the reason behind this is that he did not have  any arms (PC ers out there he liked the nick name, he found it empowering ). He got by via a network of chains around his neck and an incredibly vivacious character. Very inspiring.
Then to Nasca and lines: Astrological calendar, fertility symbols, shaman guides or alien landing strip. You decide.

Then off we go sand surfing sounds easy, sliding down gentle slops, but oh no. Nobody tells you that you have to get there on foot. We set out at 9am a two hour trek which can only be described as a quarry path, We then reach the White Mountain which basically amounts to  a giant sand dune. We pay our respect to the mountain by giving it a drink of our water before we take our first step onto the sand. We then begin the hours assent. Mad dogs, four men and a English woman, go walking up a bloody great sand dune in the mid day sun.

After one attempt at standing up i resort to sliding down on my nether regions, Mick of course is  a natural until he has to stop, but he pulls off a magnificent somersault leaving him grazed and bruised. Battered and bleeding we complete a forty minute walk back to the car. We have sand in places we never realised existed.

After a 13 hour over night bus journey to Cusco I foolishly start to think I've conquered the art of urinating in a moving vehicle. Step 1:- Hold on with one arm whilst untying your trousers with the other  hand, keeping knees relaxed to absorb any unexpected bumps. Step 2:- Strategically hover over the stenching toilet, one hand turning white gripping on for life whilst the other holding on to your trousers in an attempt to keep them away from the toilet rim. Then suddenly I realise I've skipped  a step and forgot to get the toilet roll first, desperately I pounce for the toilet roll just as the bus swings round a corner I'm propelled against the toilet door and my dignity disappears down the chemical loo. Ladies please forward any alternative techniques.

Cusco is great, although we have not done much yet, although a cup of coca tea at the hotel John Peel died was 3 times more expensive than the norm, all in china and silver. See Video below. Also there's Cusco locals dancing for the virgin video. Please download, don't stream. Here's some pictures...

title: Halos, Meteors and Earthquakes
description: Yes we've had space rocks and earthquakes in our path, also halo's around the sun and three different hostels giving us room 104 (Watermeadows) in a row, but this wasn't due to ingesting San Pedro as we where too scared (old) to do that, but all the same there are weird things afoot.

Machu Picchu is not weird though, it is magnificent and we spent around 10 hours there just wandering around the huge site and sitting in the shade of the terraces. Expensive to get to (we went the lazy root – by train) but well worth it.

We've also gone right through the sacred valley and eaten in the fallen angle and witches garden. All swilled down with vast amount of booze. But as requested less words, more videos (when I get a faster connection) .....

title: Found him
description: We heard vicious rumours that Paddington had packed up his belongings and moved to a retirement village in Spain but Hurrrraaaahhhhh, we at last find evidence that our small furry friend Paddington is safe and well in Peru, see if you can spot him.

We headed to Arequipa and from there took a trip to Coca Canyon that is deeper than the Grand Canyon so of course it would be rude not to climb down it. Four hours later and some wear and tear on our legs, we get to the bottom.

We meet a great group of people to spend a few days with but in no time  at all it becomes apparent that they are much younger and fitter than myself and mick. So after spending the night at the bottom of the Canyon instead of making the long climb to the summit we take Mules.
I of course get the largest lead mule and Mick gets the micro mule with no saddle. We end our journey by watching Condors and a visit to the hot springs a staggering 35 degrees.

Next we make  our pilgrimage to Lake Titicaca. Altitude, sun and wind at the lake take their toll and we are as red as very red berries that have been painted very bright red. Idiots. The lake was beautiful and the reed islands and the Aymey people were fascinating. I think their way of life truly has a lot to offer. When a family has  a dispute they simply chop the island up and float off and during community festivals they tie all the island together. They have been doing this longer than America has existed. Anyway... Bye Peru, Hola Bolivia!

title: Coca Sun
description: Peru buses are full of fellow tourists. Ecuador buses are not, the odd chicken, the epanades hawker, but very few tourist. Bolivian buses are much the same, except the passengers tend to tell the driver to vamose! And women sleep on the floor, some passenger actually get in with the luggage under the bus as well. Anyway the bus going around the lake from Peru to Bolivia was full of tourists. In fact the bus from Copacabana to La Paz was full of tourists, it even stopped so people could take photos just as we descended into the city.  Anyway the bus full of internationals gets to the border for a meaningless ritual. We have to get out the bus, get papers, give away papers, pay 1 bob and walk into Bolivia.

Before we know it we are in Copacabana. The evil Manalow song is dancing our head. It is a sea resort for Bolivians, although it is no sea, its still lake Titicaca. We look in vain to find street signs, but do find a wonderus hostel that looks over the bay, with a really great restaurant where we eat and booze.

The next day we get up early and head for the island of the sun. The ferry slowly makes it way around to the north island. We walk the three hours to the south side, where the ferry will take us back. All is good, although our sandwiches have melted into their paper bags, we are still loving it.

Then we make the mistake. We go right. We should have gone left. We walk down the steep mountain path for around half an hour. Sitting in the scummy bay recovering from our decent we start to wonder where are the other ferry goers are. Times ticking on and the ferry is the last ferry. We ask a local fisherman in very broken Spanish. Shit, the other side of the island! We have half an hour to make it. Running up a steep hill at 4000 meters in full sun shine isn't that funny. Up to the top and flying down the other side. We do make it, all red faced and covered in sweat. Oh well.

I hope your adventure will continue to be a great experience. By the way, Mikey (Mills) sent me the link to your blog and I'm the one from Swiss  who loves him dearly :0)
Take good care

comments.author: mar
content: Sounds like hard work to me!

title: Aaaarrrrraahhhh!
description: Humpf our bags on to our backs, check out the hostel, make our way to getting on the bus chaos. Say good bye to Copacabana and the one shoe shine boy, the drunken night with locals in the gratified bar and all of its half understood boozy chats.

Bus went as normal until: Wait! Get off the bus. The bus goes on one shaky ferry boat, we pay for another. The Bolivian Navy (!?) run this crossing as they have nothing else to do, we sit watching the bus bob up and down on a ferry behind us as we cross.
Bang! We are in La Paz and its hilly and crazy. Pollution: tick, Pirated dvd's: tick, lama foetus: tick, Arrange the bike ride for death road: tick.

DEATH ROAD is a one lane decent just outside of La Paz, and so called, as around 4 years ago on this gravel and dust path that is carved out of the mountainside, it was found to have an average of one fatality per day. The deadliest road in the world. This in mind, a new road was started and the formally two way road was made into a one way that changed direction at certain times of day, making the laughable reversing spots death traps redundant. Now most of the traffic uses  the new road, although a few villages that cling on to the side of death road make use of it.

Its not the road side memorials, or rusted twisted metal of truck and bus carcases that make you careful cycling down, it's the sheer drops. Also the gravel makes it a very slippy ride, especially as you tend to use the brakes most time and you don't have a truck's weight to help you stick to the edge.

So we set out from the snowy peaks at a height of 4800 meters above sea level.  Our hands gloved and cold, our shoulders and upper backs soon to hurt. Roughly five hours later having travelled 40.6 mile whilst descending 3600 meters having stripped off our clothing on the way down due to the rise in temperature, butterflies and fauna we make it through waterfalls, streams and a few skids. Knackerd and a little saddle sore we have a beer before chilling at Coroico.

The next day we get a taxi with Quetchin women to a t-junction to pick up our 18 hour bus trip to Rurrenbaque. This road is not dissimilar to the death road: one lane, hair pin bends and reversing spots. Claire has to swap seats with me, so not be next to the window. Sleeping pills and "Colour me Kubrick" on the zen does not help the hellish time in a bus seat but once again we make it.

comments.author: Karl
content: Damn, you survived the death road!  I had the memorial all picked out - it was going to have your faces etched into the plaque with love hearts, and flowers, and plummeting bicycles and everything.  Oh well, I'll hang onto the designs - you've still a few months left to go.
Well tonight I'll have to attempt cycling home along the canals after several liters of Belgium's finest.  I'd like to see you try that, ya big pansies.

Went to hear Chilean ensemble last week - very noisy!
Lovely sunny morning here in France - must go and garden.

title: Bolivian white stuff
description: We make our way down to the middle of no where - Uyuni. On the way we pass through a city where some dodgy bloke whipped my pop out of my hands. The Peruvian earthquake cause a maximum security prison to spill its contents, there are some 150 still at large, maybe he was one of them. Also we pass through the white city of Sucre and Potasi the highest and one of the most pillaged cities in the world.

Slowly we snake through the desert to Uyuni were we get our visas stamped to exit Bolivia and we book our trip to the salt plains. After a chilli night and purchasing of thick (not so sexy) black woolly legins we are very excited and some what nervous about the tour. We have read that it can reach -25 degrees in the evening. With no sleeping bag trusting the booking agent that lots of blankets will be available, we head off. Two Swiss, two Dutch and mick and I squish into  a 4 by 4's with the driver his wife and child . It soon becomes apparent that the guide and his wife only speak Spanish. Oh well.

The first stop was a train graveyard just out side of Uyuni. We soon discover that universal gesturing isn't ample to describe its history so after clambering over the trains for a few pics we are off. Apparently the train tracks of south America resemble a great big hand, taking their natural resources out to the ports. I guess when the continent could not be exploited any more is when the trains started to rust.

The ground gradually becomes whiter until we are in the thick and vast Salar de Uyuni. Bright white flat landscape stretching out to meet the horizon. Sun glasses are  a must as the glare of the white salt reflecting the sun at altitude is quite blinding. I have an over whelming urge to run around and cartwheel like an idiot and lick the salt, so of course I do and of course Mick joins me in our mad half hour. Once we are breathless which doesn't take long at altitude we visit the 'Salt Eyes'. Areas where the salt crust is so thin that the water underneath the salt bubbles to the surface. It looks like the water is boiling hot but as we plunge our hand into the water we only find that it is freezing cold.

We stop at Colchani a salt processing village to watch the men at work scraping the salt from the ground into a truck.  One man building a church out of the salt blocks and women making trinket boxes and ornaments from the salt. After a short drive we arrive at the Salt Hotel. Although almost unique (as there are two) it proves to be novel rather than inspiring but it has a small turquoise pool at its front where you can see the salt crystals forming that have a pearl like iridescent sheen about them. A fairies play ground.

The real weirdness continues when we drive across the salt plain to something called fish island, which is basically a island of dead coral with huge cacti on it some reaching over ten metres allegedly hundreds of years old. Very odd. People keep referring to the salt as ice and all is strange. We run around a bit more, before driving off to a mud walled village on the edge of the plain.

We are in one unheated room. The village is empty, although the Swiss women finds a door that opens on to some blokes house who is selling amongst other things beer. We and the Dutch couple get some beer in and before we know it we are trying to sleep on the ultra soft valley like mattresses. Its not cold though. Next we head out to a volcanic lake to see hundreds of flamingos, foxes and see the four wheel drives put to the test. The Jeep sort of climbs up the very uneven rock path, almost feel it push down on each wheel in a walking manner. I thought they were designed to drop your kids of at school.

In the centre of Salvador Dali Desert there are some bizarre rock formations that have been formed by the howling winds. Any how, we pass Laguna Colorada, natural blood red lakes caused by algae and we are off to another lodge for more beers and a very early rise.

We wake and leave around 4am, its very very cold. Around -9 but there are millions of stars glitter over head. We head over to see some geezers doing there stuff at an altitude of 5000 meters. The sight is amazing the sun rising casts our shadows over the steam emerging from the steaming pools of mud. I am very very very very cold, but its the only time of day they do this. Although the sun rises and instantly it gets warmer and clothes are shed.

We make our ways to the hot springs, but its too cold to get undressed, although its good to dip our feet in and take away the cold numbness. Then we visit our last natural beauty the Laguna Verde, natural green volcanic lake caused by arsenic and other minerals. The Volcan Lieancabur is reflected perfectly and it is airily quiet. The volcano lies in the middle of the Bolivia Chile border. We wave goodbye to Bolivia and it feels like goodbye to South America, as Chile feels European. Its hot in the town we arrive in, really hot, walking in the shadows hot. The prices here shoot up and we loose our focus. We ignore the English cove, wine tours and astronomy and get down to Santiago after a quick stop off for a cold picnic on the beach. Soon we leap across the ocean, leaving the bad Spanish behind and landing on Samhain (Halloween).

title: Rangi Kai
description: So we got out of Chile ah! Now we are in the bay of islands ah! We went to Auckland eh! We where spun out and grumpy on high prices and jet lag eh! Oh and also five hours waiting in a Chilean airport, 13 hour flight with over excited Argentinian and Brazilian teenage sports people and then another five hours waiting for the hostel to open eh!

This didn't stop us hiring a van and booking a trip up north. The van cost us around a grand (English) for 50 days. The first Auckland hostel had a rule on every wall and rivets on the stairs that sent Claire flying. So we went to another.

Back to Santiago, we did climb a city hill and saw the palm trees, greenery, buildings and smog. However, the smog was nothing compared to other cities we've been (Harry). Also we did go out in a groovy university area and met some balloon benders, they didn't know Paxo though. Talking of Paxo, for those know him, he should now be slowly returning from kicking butt in Israel or is that climbing olive trees and sticking onions up his nose.

Samhain was celebrated under the tree who's roots were as big as the branches and we then head off out for a meal. Mick's first curry in four months. Too tired and grumpy to see in the new year we sleep. Next day we went to the Auckland Museum, which was great, although very big and we ran out of time and missed out the history of Auckland on the top floor and some world war two stuff.

Another highlight was Maorioke on TV which is.... like pop idol but with Maori's. All full on tattooed faces but very genuine and articulate musical criticism. Also got drunk with a two islanders that where on holiday in Auckland but are now living in Australia. We also met a widower from the south island as the fireworks went off outside the smoking shack. On the real bomb fire night we where meant to go to the beach but the rain was relentless and it hasn't really stopped yet.
We pick up the van on Thursday the 8th and Claire is shitting her self about driving it.....

title: Get in the van
description: Well we left the popping sound of the shrimps at the mangroves of the bay of islands behind and headed back on the "no eating or drinking" bus. We then slogged our bags up back to the trusty international kiwi hotel and back to our much anticipated Chilli that we had waiting for us in the fridge there.

Tomorrow was the day. Tomorrow we picked up the van. We wake fumble around and get the link bus over town before arriving at the van depot. Before we know it Claire is commanding our new beast through the hectic crossovers of Auckland. Driving the van took some getting used too. Claire legs gave away with nervousness and hands turned into two buckets of sweat. But any way it was straight on to the mess of lanes that leads out of Auckland! Quiet hellish, five hours later and Claire is now capable of driving rick's bus. Maybe...  We head out of the city and to the west cost and the surfing (and surfing accident tv program) town of Pihi. Amazing.

We get a camp site for 20 dollars a night and head out on to the beach. Before we know it we are cooking curries, climbing the loin (which is a huge rock type mountain on the beach), climbing through the woodland, watching waterfalls and enjoying a jug of ale at the bowling club. Once you leave the city everything disappears, including petrol stations and shops. We are slowly getting used to it.

Next we aim across to the other coast and the hot water beach. Very long windy drive that takes us across very south American type roads. The white roads from one coast to the other are windy and without tarmac. Yes pampered Liz might be looking at us from the currency but all is not the same here.

Johnny, you would have love thr hot water beach, perfect for building dams and channels and with the added advantage you can scowled the poor fella that's trying to relax in a sand pool just below your network. Its very odd, there's the sea and its freezing, but if you dig a hole in the sand here, its very, very hot, when the waters run into each other its sends the sensors in your feet a bit dolally.

We also went and for a walk to look at Cathedral cave, all very impressive, natural and free. But not long before we where back in the van and travelling down to Rotorua where we are currently at and trying to keep within budget. Although most days we can spend walking around a lake or through red woods and listen to the trees creak like doors in the wind before coming back on site and jumping in the steam pool to relax and let the thoughts of dates, money, plans turn into the feast we are gonna cook in the steam oven. Steam and ugly sulphar smells are every where.  All the houses around here have hot water steam pools and all the campsites and hotels also. Steam comes up from the drains and sometimes bubbles through the concrete.  Don't stray from the path or the geezers will get you. After a good sit in the pool you become dozzy, the day is grillaint and the food was yumally.

The Napian (Art Deco city of the north island) camp site handyman (not the owner he's from the UK) says NZ is experience the youth drain, well after the brain and the skills drain. Also the English and the Americans are buying up the land and ruining it. He said that the 4 million kiwi people have been lucky to keep back the tied until now, but the future is bleak.

We have found more  LP's on Claire's Zen and cheap wine, although the van has no plugs so everything that needs charging up is now flat. Hungry ducks everywhere and a lot of other weird walking birds with weird random song. We also saw black swans (Zoe they do exist!).
Happy birthday Paul (a fellow 21ster) last birthday as a single man.

title: Leaving the North
description: So we left the free hot pool and headed south to the lake of Rotorua and a free camp site. Lake Rotorua is nearly as big as Singapore and is the home to the odd flying plane. The beautiful free camp site a gently bubbling lake surrounded by grand old trees with Tuis perched in them there bizarre song echoing around us. The site looked like it had some permanent residents and there was a huge fire on Friday night. We stayed two days and took it easy daydreaming by the waters edge and feeding the ducks and ducklings, only going into town for supplies.

The next day we where going to head to Napier to see the art deco buildings and drink wine. This all changed, we decided to head towards the three volcanoes and the mountain called mount doom and Mordor in the lord of the rings film (sorry Gunner) but alas no sighting of Bill boo Bagins or Smegle. Any how we drove to a camp site and booked some transport to take us to the start of the track. Rummaging around in the van we found our boots still in there bleach plastic bags that we had to do entering NZ. They take the environment very seriously and you can see why. They x-ray your bags entering the country just in case you've ignored there advice at declaring certain items or you are carrying fruit etc. Instant fine if you do.

On to the walk which cost us 35 dollars each to get to and seemed a bit of a rip off. We left our names and details with the bus company in case we didn't make it for the last bus at 4.30pm and we set off on the 8 hour journey. The walk was amazing although South America has spoilt us a bit. The Devils Staircase and 'devils cat litter tray' ( 45 minute ascent and 25 minute ascent respectively) remind us how unfit we are. There where a lot of people concerned about how fast they where doing the crossing, although we where too, as the bus driver said if you where not back by 4:30 they would go with out you and phone search and rescue. Nice.

We set off at 8am and completed the walk jelly legged and walk drunk by 2.30pm. This was nothing to the people limbering up on the bus to the start no doubt. It was a great day and included some snow ball fights, strange views, a Beech wood, blue and emerald coloured glowing lakes and stinky sulphur all on a virtual tourist conveyor belt of the sweating and panting.

The next day the water was not warm on the camp site, Claire got our money back $ 28 whoo whoo and we headed to Wellington after a chip picnic on the way we end up on the outskirts of Welli ready for films, gigs, curry and all the trappings of this great city

comments.author: mar
content: Glad to hear from you again.  A slower pace of life in NZ I think.

content: Well I suppose I have to leave a comment since I complained about them being broken, and then you fixed them.
Hmm, don't really have anything to say.  Think I'll have a sandwich.

title: Southern Arrival
description: Well, we are a billion blogs behind (about three). We left the north island on Friday the 23rd and now it's only 21 days to Christmas, which is very odd as it's chocolate melting summer here.

Anyway, we eat a curry in Wellington and want to see movies and gigs, but after we move out of the campsite/car park we are in hoping to camp on the Quay side, we find out the best ferry to get is in an hours time, unfortunate we have yet to go  to the Indian Embassy and sort out our Visa. It  looks like we will  have to wait until we get to Australia, where we envisage homeless new years and  lots of messing around.

But wait I'm getting ahead of myself, in Wellington we did have a day going up the hill on the hundred year old trolley car and walking through the gardens to the city as well as consuming curry. Did I mention we had a curry. Yes a curry. Yum a curry.

The north island sort of pails as we reach the empty highways of the south island. The crossing was great, all wind in the bay of the north island and then in to the green maze that greats you as you head into Piction.

According to Maori tradition a Maori leader set sail in his boat (the south island) to go fishing. He caught a large fish that he bought to the surface ( the north island) and there it stayed until his brothers got hungry and and took big bites out of it. Any hu.

We go straight to Canvastown which was called this due to it being a town of tents for a year whilst people rushed around after gold, this is the story of much of the south island. The camp site we decide to stay in is in an amazing setting next to a crystal clear river (which soon we discover, every river is in the south island). This is rural, the kitchen has a dozen flies darting around and it all has the feel of a Steven King movie. There are old turned up posters in  the TV room about the gold rush and creaking swings in the breeze. Everything is lazy and dead as we are in the shoulder season. Apparently this place fills up in December, but tonight we see one man sit in the TV room on his own surrounded by darkness  serial killer, no doubt. We park up and go for a walk through the feral woods full of tree spirits and trixy pixies to a spooky cave to watch the glow worms do there thing. Then it's back to the van to get bitten to death by a zillion sand flies. As the van gets taken over I Claire become a sand fly serial killer. (it was either them or me). We later learn that it is only the female that bites in order to obtain protein to produce her young. How guilty did I feel !

Next day, we are still alive and we want to head north to Marahau and sea kyaking, seal watching and big beaches. This we do and manage to find a parking place overlooking this wide beach which does not have a no camping sign. Result! The tide here is remarkable and goes out into the distance leaving cockles, cusion star fish and mud skipers that tickle your feet behind . Before you know it the tide is back in. Apparently it goes out at the speed of 2cm a minute. On our first night we watch a wonderful sun melt into the sea to be followed by clear sky and an almost full moon. On the full moon a group of women gather on the beach, pagans no doubt, but to my surprise they were sat around howling Queen songs. ( George is clearly not on her own.) We go for a tramp through the reserve and the sun flickers through the great verity of trees. We see  a pair of Quails with about nine chicks  they are hilarious. They have wings but for some reason they refuse to use them and run round like demented souls. I (Claire) add to my list of misdemeanour's and become  a camp-site water thief.

The next day after shopping around we get a half day kayaking to see split apple rock and paddle through the granite caves near by and the rest of the day up the coast past an island with one invisible seal on to the incredible, but fast walk back down the coast. We paddle back to the boat which should be taking us back to the bay where the van is. But no the tide is out so we have another hour walk through the reserve back to the van. A long day.

I didn't mention Nelson did I, well we passed it on the way up and its great little town with a huge golden beach. No matter, we head back there and stay in the car park near the beach, which Claire finds out via some fellow sleeping-in-a-van Germans that it is ok to park in over night.

Four days without a shower begins to take control of our sanity so we finally come to term with paying for  a campsite. So its off to the west coast to see sun set over Carters Beach, although we find that its too windy to stay out. We check in to a holiday camp and wash and charge everything up and cook a curry which we will eat in various forms over the next few days.

From my beach we go down the coast and see blow holes and pancake rocks, seals and the cheeky wood hen or western Welke. All good, then its on to the Glaciers! But that's for next time, as is the  astounding Haase pass, the amazing Wanaka, the dull Queenstown and  comedy moustaches ... etc etc....

title: Clairely Foxy
description: After making quicker than expected progress we find ourselves in cooler air around the Franz Josef Glacier. According to Maori tradition a girl was mesmerised by the mountains and convinced her lover to walk amongst the mountains, her lover fell to his death and she cried and cried until her tears fell for so long that she caused and avalanche which lead to the creation of the Glaciers.  At 6pm we find the local guide office open and with some trepidation ( after the agent saying we had to be pretty fit and have good  knee bendage) we book ourselves on the eight hour hike around the Glacier. We spend the night in a car park with no toilet. The only toilet they do have in town costs 50 cents and is fully automated with toilet roll measured for you, what ever business you have planned to conduct in there. The best/worst thing about HAL is that it starts to blare out mid flow   What the world needs now is love sweet love.

As night falls the van starts to get colder but the stars get brighter and we see four shooting stars. Waking up to the sound of giant angry wasps (or helicopters) and a wonderful view of the snow capped mountain. The helichoppers here are not used for weather or police which is all good, but tourists which is ok.

We have a humungus faff as we are all fitted out with climbing gear: Boots, crampons etc. Hurrah we finally approach the awesome glacier. We attach our crampons and take our first stiff steps onto the ice.

Throughout the day the guides constantly chip away at the ice to maintain the steps, Mick observed that the smashed pieces of ice resembled a Sneinton carpark. Up we trudged hanging on for dear life as we hauled ourselves up the steps pulling on to the ropes to assist our accent.  As we get towards the top each guide with a  maximum of eight people find their own unique way around the Glacier:  Climbing up and down ladders carved in the ice, slipping through vertical slides making our bodies somehow mould themselves for us to glide through impossible slits of concrete ice. Mick's camera runs out of juice and my camera freezes so no more pictures until a kind German steps in to take pics that we hopped he would email.

A wonderful experience. The water flows down the glaciers and into a very clear river which some time experiences a tsunami like wave when a huge peace of ice falls off the ice cave from where the river starts. The whole mountain is being chewed up by this and the colour of the snow starts to blend into the colour of the mountain at its base. Glaciers are constantly growing or receding. This one is growing at the moment, summer time. There are also some cheeky Kea that want walkers food. We didn't find Yoda's cave or superman's hide out, although we are sure it's there somewhere. Back off the snow we  are shattered and aching. So we celebrate with a glass of wine or three back at the van. The next day we decide to drive to Foxes Glacier and who should we meet in the secluded car layby but our German saviour, we down load the pics and head towards our next adventure.

The glaciers where called Victoria and Albert but Julius von Haast renamed them to Austro-Hungarian emperor and prime minster Fox in the last 1800's. You'll hear about that Dutchman on the next blog as we battle away through his pass....

title: Road Tripped
description: Leaving the ice behind us, we visit blow holes and pancake rocks that are carved out of the west coast. All is good and free and makes the journey turn into an adventure, with welks, walks and views. These sights peeted out as we take the small road down to Jackson bay to a campsite there for recharging ourselves, and cleaning etc.
The camp was building up to this huge wedding to be held the following day on the beach. All the local land owners attending and

top chiefs where gonna cook all day and everything was champaign and guests from abroad. Almost every older person we meet has close relatives who live in the UK or else where. They are downing a few drinks around a pre wedding bbq. We get advised that the Haast pass is some of the best scenery that NZ has to offer. This is good news as its where we are headed there next and we are not disappointed around every corner is something new, huge alpine mountains, great mistletoe woods
and blue lakes
The road crosses many creeks and all have names, including Robinson Creek, but no wolf creek, phhhew! Creek spotting is a good game.

We soon arrive at Wanaka, which is this neat little town which focus is a great clear lake that is fed from icy water from the surrounding snowy peaks. It's hot and kids are swimming in the freezing lake and people are just sun bathing by the shore. All is good apart from the no camping signs that are in every car park. So we head just out of town to Albert town which has a superb DOC (Department of Conservation) campsite, which is only 14 dollars a night. We didn't pay on our first night due to semi-confusion on how we get a receipt that we have to display on our vehicle. Due to this, the warden wakes us up and explains all and also lets us off the charge for that night. We do pay the next night. The site is dwarfed by huge pine trees and there is a clear gloopy (as its so cold) river that runs around it. Also there is a strange concrete grave yard that we didn't discover to just before left.

Sad to go, we leave for Queenstown, which we almost stay in. The campsite is rubbish, expensive and much like a carpark. Claire gets our money back and we leave. But before we do, we indulged ourselves in a bit of jet boat action at Shootover River. The powerful beast has us wet in no time and we are off towards Milford Sounds.

Te Anau is our stop off on the way. We book into a campsite and charge and cook sheep-less potato top or Shepard-less pie. The town sits around a huge lake and we go to the DOC centre and get local info about walks and DOC campsites. They have a wildlife reserve there also, where we get to see a lot of cheeky critters and learn that Kea have a tendency to eat cars tyres and really should not be encouraged or fed.

The next day is another wonderful day driving up Milford road which is just amazing and does not come across on our photos. Travelling towards Milford you have to drive through this dripping dank dark death tunnel that goes through one of the huge mountains and has traffic lights at either end. It was very unexpected and put another credit on bears outstanding driving record.

We get there and it's beautiful but really there is just a ferry port with no campsite. So we have to head back through the tunnel and find the nearest site, we head down Hollyford track to a back water sand fly reserve that is owned by the descendent of Mr Gunn (a big name around these parts). Its a wonderful basic place, powered by generators and has a certain old hippy charm and a huge hollow tree called hells bells, that looks like the tree off sleepy hollow. The only bad thing is sand flies are everywhere and they drink up your blood like wine. Moari legend maintains that they are there to prevent people from becoming lazy in the beautiful Fiordland. Also the flying kiwi adventure bus is here, which seems to be following us. We would have stayed here longer, looking at the free museum and go for more drunken walks in search of glow worms in the pitch black, but the sand fly just suck, suck and suck.

So we leave and go back down Milford road and walk around mistletoe lake, stop off back in Te Anau before heading to Clifden to stay next to a free DOC campsite near the unused but historic Clifden suspension bridge. And we are not even in Bristol.

We sleep well and head for Clifden caves to see glow worms the next morning (ok, afternoon). The caves are a bit hairy, lots of sliding head first etc and with our failing torch, we nesh it and get back in the van, just after a bunch of children come out with head torches on. Enough of crawling around slimy caves in the dark and banging our heads, we are off to the south coast via Invercargil for charging, food buying petrol and booze. The town is a horrid functional grid and has lots of punky type kids disobeying the no skateboard signs. We soon leave and head for a doc and trampoline campsite in Papatowai. The scenery changes yet again the rolling hills are so perfectly formed they resemble the telly tubby hills and the hundreds of sheep dotted across them remind us of fuzzy felts. A bit of a confusing drive, but we get to this tiny town and the campsite is cheap and had all amenities that you would find at a commercial campsite and its next to the beach and it had a trampoline. Did I mention the trampoline of industrial size. Yes that's right a trampoline and mini mini bunnies and great fan tail martial art type birds twirling around catching insects. Also Gordon the weird warden.

The next couple of days we have walks around the beach and picnics and generally chill for a bit, before heading back along the coast to porpoise bay to try to see dolphins (we fail), but we do see the rare yellow-eyed penguins and sea loins on the beach, very amazing. Its quite bizarre to see penguins on a sunny sandy beach and their chicks in the surrounding bush. They don't teach you that in school.

title: Yellow-eyed Hop
description: The Catlins is a great area. This became even more apparent as we headed up to Dunedin, due to the  rain and everything that was free, such as penguin watching, suddenly had a price tag. Dunedin  was purchased from the  Moari for a song by a bunch of Scottish and the Scotts eventually settled here a couple of years later. The city takes after Edinburgh, it even has a Princes Street. Its very arty and costly. We went straight out to the Otago Peninisula and found a secluded lay by with a great view of the beach and set up camp. We saw a Royal Albatross that day, but didn't get that close as it cost 35 dollars each. They have a wing span of 3-5 meters and mate for life, but they separate to fly around the world in opposite directions, returning to the same breeding ground once every two years. They share the 11 week incubation period and then fly off on their lonely way.

We went back to the hilly town of Dunedin and spent a night listening to the local student radio. The next day we left, with a lengthy stop off at the odd spherical alien like rocks at Moeraki. The mountainside seems to give birth to these balls of rock. Then it was a great leap forward into Peel Forest where the van's sliding door stopped locking that left the van unsecured and unable to move. Hell! Claire phoned the AA. After talking to the DOC grounds man he saw what was wrong with the door. He was great bloke: An ex-farmer and now is some what of a traveller. Anyway it was three bolts that had fallen off from the inside of the door . We got charged a call out fee, but Claire is oh so determined to get it back from the van hire people. From the beginning of December (not the end of summer) the towns around here have xmas decorations and even decorated trees although it seems a bit odd. We have now tinselled up our van and are gonna have a roast of sorts on the 21st. Happy birthday Johnny.

We head to Christchurch and find a camp and eat reheats. Nice city but before we know it we are off again heading to Arthur pass. Me hobbling along with flippity flop walking wounds . We go through Sheffield (no anvil) and Springfield (no Homer) and to Arthur Pass Village which is situated in a rainy little valley by a railway track. We go to the deserted DOC campsite, only to be greeted by a noisy kea, clip clopping on the tin roof and poking his beak down at us. Is this good luck... time will tell.

Arthur's pass just seems like a rain trap, fingers from the sky tapped at our roof all night and so did a kea (see video, when we up load some videos). So we left the rain for Hanmer and hot springs. A long day of driving and we get there. We park up and relax. Next day we leave for the better springs down the road, well an hour down the road.

We plunge into the black pools thick with ash and the early morning struggles float away. But the sand fly are back and eating Bears nose and the paranoid fly float around us like a cloud. The anticoagulant the flies generously give you don't half make you itch the next day. We get away from them and go to the inside pools. No flies but they are segregated as people go nude into these rooms. Luckily we are the only people there and we individually slide into the dark velvety waters in the Japanese bathrooms. Bliss.

Revitalised we drive back past Hanmer and on the east coast and the whale watching town of Kaikoura. After a day of rest, we head out into the sea and see whales dive and dusty dolphins jump which was of course amazing. Now Christmas looms near, less than a week and we must head back to Christchurch for a Yule festival meal and shed a tear as we say goodbye to our van. No more moshing to the clash as we trundle down the road, no more late night listening to podcasts and learning about good music sites like http://www.stereogum.com or http://www.daytrotter.com. Also we had a voice reply on a podcast to email we sent asking them about Melbourne. They told us what to do and where to go, its sounds great. Anyway, back to the no mores. No more driving to the cliff edge and watching the Bull Kelp lap around like hair. No more watching the temperature jump form 10 to 27 degrees in matter of hours. No more bear spitting out toothpaste in high gales and watching it disappeared from the side to the back of the van. Maybe this is a good thing as the AA are about to go on strike here. We will soon be in Sydney,  homeless and skint. The year is ending and all I'm thinking is what's happened to frog watch johnny and why do people use facebook, it's rubbish.

comments.author: Joris
content: GrmblGrmbl.. Stop having fun over there and come back here for some proper ass-freezing!

comments.author: mar
content: Happy Chrimbo! We think about you all the time - squirrels a bit thin on the ground here at the moment - it is quite cold!

comments.author: Mikey Mills (Metal Mick)
content: Mick.. dude... Hope your going to have a great xmas  on your travels... Its damn cold in the uk. i came over to see my Girlie in swiss for xmas... but alas its not warmer... -5 today.... Xmas in Switzerland will be a low key affair nice and quiet with some scrummy Veggie food. Keep on the good travel and the will get my attention more now im internet enabled again.

title: Some Missing NZ Films... (Part 1)
description: Here some New Zealand films that I've just been able to upload...

title: Cheeky
description: A short film about a Kea...

title: Back in the way-back machine.
description: Christmas is over, New year has broke and now Claire and I are trying to claw back some energy at the edge of the blue mountains just outside of Sydney. We need to return to Sydney in a couple of days: One, for the street festival and two, to pick up our passports from the Indian High commission (hopefully). Then its off to Melbourne.

It seem like a long time ago since we left NZ. It's a place of a lot of firsts: The first place in the world to get a welfare state program; The first place the women's suffrage movement got the vote; The first transgender mp in 1999 and first rasta MP.  Also the Kiwi's take environmental issues seriously, although some Germans would disagree, complaining about the crop spraying and bad recycling. They still have no nuclear power and refuse American nuclear war ships to dock in their harbours. The remains of Rainbow warrior are is still in Auckland after the French blew it up. The indignations population (Maori) seem to be more reconsigned than other post colonies, with land reclaim and social contracts. Although there are some dark history concerning Chinese settlers. Not a bad place at all, although we met a few racist macho sexist Kiwi and some concerned about the amount of laws being brought in - Rules for fools. Although lot of Kiwi are leaving for the 30% wage hike in Australia. We also went over to Australia after early morning taxi ride with a cook islander driver. We pay our departure tax and fly off to Sydney.

But hold on I'm getting ahead of myself. On the morning of the 22nd , at 4.30am we head out in the dark towards a field. Here the sun starts to rise after the longest day and we climb into a wicker basket and ascend gracefully into the clear sky. I've always wanted to go into a balloon and it didn't disappoint. Some farmers hate them, some like them and the cows in the field we landed in seemed very curious. Amazing experience and learnt a lot about being held up just by hot air. The Balloons last about 500 flights and are made in Bristol. After we scare some cows on landing, we drink sham-cider and  head back to the camp site to clean up the van. This as you may guess is quiet a long process and sad. We will miss the van. 5310 KM in 46 days  and it was a great time. We were expecting problems handing the van back, but it all seem to go smoothly.

We had had our xmas dinner on the Johnny's birthday, went out for Thai on our 2nd anniversary but on xmas day itself we had beans on to toast. However, later Christmas day, we went hunting for food, and eventually we found only one Thai restaurant open. The street it was on had hundreds of other places to eat but where resting. The food there though was surprisingly good.
The one thing we got through the post to the hostel was from the might Karl. A five disc digital surprise and a surprise horse. Hat's off to you Karl, buy you a curry in India.

The thing about Sydney to me is: Bats. They have these great fruit bats or flying foxes, they just hang like fruit from the trees in the botanical gardens, all wrapped up in their leathery wings and then fly across the city at dusk. They are actually ginger and very big. I wonder what Molly would make of them??

It's was very touch and go if we where gonna get a place to stay new years eve. We had some good luck one couple who booked a double en suite room fail to show and we where able to take full advantage. On New Years Eve we also got a good position to stand (although it could have been closer to the bogs) between  Sydney harbour bridge and just across the water from the opera house. We get down there about mid day and there is a sea of umbrellas, not for the rain but to hide from the sweltering sun. We quickly run off and buy our own. It then starts to happen. By-planes flying over, other planes writing messages in the sky. Whistles are being handed out. All was fine and dandy until, of course, at 10pm, I predictably become desperate for the loo. It takes me 30 mins to get through the crowd and then there is a huge queue for anyone to relieve themselves. I finally start to fight my way through the crowd to try and get back to Mick who has all the money, cards and train passes and we have no emergency meeting place. So faced with impending doom I push, plead explain and eventually break down until I rest in the arms of Mick to the surrounding crowds surprise. Hurah!! The surrounding crowd included a Australian who worked in png and a Sikh guy, who Mick was ranting with. Also we met a cool couple from Munich and Manchester that where upholding a 5 year long distance relationship. Respect. The fireworks light up the bay, the ships turn on their outline light strips. Bang 2008! Hope you had a good time.

comments.author: Karl
content: Happy New Year Peeps.  I guess they didn't need to fill that balloon with so much hot air once Mick got on board.  Boom Boom!
Have a good time in Ozzy land!!!

comments.author: Tim
content: Hey Mick, Whats your email address, tim?

title: Fly times
description: 2008, it was time to leave Sydney for the Blue Mountains. One short train ride from central and we where there at Katoomba. We booked into a huge horrible hostel and got cheap wine. Four litres of wine here costs 10 dollars. That's around 5 quid. The next day we cooked in a stinky kitchen and headed out walking through town and out the other side look for the blue mountains.

The blue haze of these hills is due to the mist the oily stuff given off by eucalyptus. Here you can see the three sisters, legend goes that a father was scared that the local bunyip would capture his daughters so when the father went away he would leave them on a shelf of  a mountain where he thought they would be safe. Needless to say the bunyip tried to get the women and so the father turned them into stone to protect them but before he knew it the bunyip chased the father. During his escape he lost his magic bone (obviously not what you want to happen) thus the three sisters remain in rock formation waiting for their father to his ruddy magic bone. Any who what's good about this walk is when you get there you already at the top and below you stretches a rolling green valley. They have flies though, Melbourne has them also but not as much and also does Ayers rock, but you can always jump in the pool to avoid them there. I should imagine there is a huge fly army waiting to drink but not bite our skin in Cairns.

Currently we are at Ayres rock resort. The soil is red, the sun is hot, the leafs and bark on the floor looks as though they have been burnt. Its formidable and dangerous: The news tells of a local couple ran out of water but got to a dry watering hole and died. Not here though, not in this hostel/hotel thing. Here the alcohol is expensive and rationed, but the pool is free and the blue dragon fly swoop across its surface twisting playfully with each other.  Its just good to fool around in the water and cool down.

Anyway after the blue mountain we returned to Sydney to another room at the same hostel. We must have slept in most of the rooms in that place. The following day was almost like new years again. It was Sydney festival and Bryan Wilson was playing for nowt. We spent the day dodging around town looking at the stuff going off and also re-visiting the bats. Before we knew it we where wandering through the Sydney streets back to our beds. The next night was spent on the greyhound to Melbourne but first we watched No country for old men. Yet another bloody film that we seem to be watching recently. Oh and we managed to get our Indian visa after much ticket taking, photocopying and doling out of Australian dollars.

We get to Melbourne and we have a few nights at the nunnery. Hellishly hot. In the 40's. We walk across town to get our washing done and a swim in the internet at world wide wash, but they have shut up shop because of the heat. This town is wonderful, but melting. We tram across town at dusk for  the moonlight cinema and Dawn rescue in the botanical gardens. A great night. We had already got a hot tip on good cheap curries from an taxi driver from Iraq. This taxi driver was from Greece and had a story or two. A few days near (ish) the beach and drinking at the Esplanade hotel and we were back on a plane again and off to the desert. We are now waiting for a night and a chance to learn about the southern hemisphere's stars. I'm currently wondering if the English gambler we met in Melbourne has won. He won his ticket for this high stake poker game over the internet and is now sponsored. He has lived in Kenya, not a place to be at the moment and has been working in casinos all his life. Now he's sat on the other side trying to get the 200,000 dollar carrot.

The flight path takes us over the red inhospitable desert and as we come into land we catch a glimpse of Ularu protruding from the earth. We alight the plane and feel the rush of warm air as the 41 degree heat greets us. We find ourselves captive at the Ayers rock resort where everything is too expensive but the sun set over Ularu was free. The rock is a truly serene site and you can't help but feel the generations of shared wisdom that has passed through this magical place. The following day was spent in the pool and a bus out to the observatory to learn of the mountain on Mars that is 26K high and reaches outside it's atmosphere. How some people want to climb it. The southern cross and the false cross. The million star cluster, the unimaginable distances and how really small the biggest thing here is.  The unchanging moon creators. The 13th star sign. How only the Chinese astrology makes a sort of sense and how I might be a rat, no looked it up I'm a metal pig and bear is a wooden tiger. Oh, happy birthday Sarah for the 13th, hope you had a good one! It's Claire's birthday next week (the 25th) we intend to be on the reef with the fishes.

Another early morning start 4am to see the sun rise at Uleru and we take a guided walk around the base to look at cave paintings and watering hole that has water all year round even when it doesn't rain for  a couple of years. The rock was created by sediment building up in a water basin then the moving of tectonic plates pushed the rock out of the earth but it is actually on its side and you can see the sediment layers lye vertically in the rock. We then go to the cultural centre which is great, but we have little time to take in all the aboriginal information. It's amazing anyone can survive out there and it wasn't so long ago that they got land rights back and where given compensation for the stolen generation.

Australia is a strange place, due to the 25 million years this continent has been isolated and free of land bridge. The tree's keep their leafs and shed their bark, some animals hop, some are horny devils and the dreams of inhabitance take some understanding. A history of racism and messing up the fragile environment by diverting water and introducing rabbits, frogs and wild camels. Maybe things would have been different if America had not won independence so forcing the  Empire to move its penal colony down under and naming the town after the home secretary  Lord Sydney.

content: It looks a bit hot.  My friend Sheila was going to an 80's concert - must have been the same one you went to.  We watched a programme on TV about earthquakes last night - scary!  My friend Friedel is in Oz at the moment - on their way to Tasmania to get some sunshine - there being a shortage of it in Nottingham.
Oh - and very happy birthday Claire! have a nicde day.

title: Bloody Spiders it's bears birthday!
description: We fly into Cairns away from the dry heat and into the wet heat. Humid. This is a resort town and has little soul. We are only here so we can get up to Cape Tribulation, where the rain forest meets the sea and where Captain cook ran into coral that messed his boat up. There's also a lot mangrove bog land as well, this apparently works with the coral. Coral is an animal that derives 95% of its food through a symbiotic relationship with photosynthesising plants. It comes all shapes sizes and colours and is a city of sea life. Really wonderful. Any hoot we get a bit of a tour up there, as its the cheapest way to get. We jump in a van,then run around a rainforest and make it up to the beach house, a collection of huts in the forest and right on the beach as well. Great place with a huge pool and bar. Also it has huge spiders, snakes, stick insects and a billion mozzies. That said, as soon as we arrive we decide we want to spend more time here. It's also croc country and whilst out walking along an empty beach (can't swim due to evil jelly fish) we see a sign saying that a salty had been spotted around that area in the last few days and to be careful. Also cassowary are about. They are like a cross between an emu and a turkey. They have a middle claw called the disembowelling claw e also and have killed people, including a 6 year old a couple of years ago. They are also endangered and are extremely important at keeping the rainforest going as they are great at distributing seeds. We did see one in the wild and they are very strange creatures. We didn't see many crocs as it was too hot for them, although we did see a mother croc guarding her eggs from a boat.

125 million years old forest that sort of hasn't changed much apart from the cane toads. Another classic opps, should not have introduced that animal Australian story. They where growing sugar cane and decide to introduce a 100 frogs which eat the bugs that eat the cane. Well that's how it works in south America, in Australia the bugs are too high up for the frogs to eat, so instead they bred like crazy upset the local food chain. They are highly poisonous and give off hallucinogenic sweat and have no natural predator. They are helping to destroy the rain forest. Also rabbits and foxes where introduce for hunting and the domestic cat is now five times as big and very feral. Also there are no red seeder trees to be found as it took loggers 25 years to take them all. Other tree's to watch out for are ones that have heart shaped leafs and grow at the edge of the forest often near paths or clearings and they are poisonous. Then there is a waitawhile which is a vine with barbs that will stick in your clothes and you have to unhook them. Is not a good idea to run through the forest and apparently a man orienteering lost an eye after brushing past a waitawhile. There are lots of barbs and hooks here.

So we are streaming with sweat and after a brief stern explanation of how the beach house works and not to leave food out as critters might go for you after they have your food. We hump our bags to our hut and then hit the pool. Where we meet a English-South-African-Australian women and her kid Jonah. She has a billion stories and all are funny and unusual. Her dad sounded quiet a character as well. Born in England, gives up his English passport to live in South Africa with his wife, who starts to die of cancer so they travel around the world, she dies. He meets an American women and moves to America, get bored and moves to Mexico where he seems to carry on drinking heavily and moving from rich widow to rich widow.

Anyway a lot of people are going on a forest at night nature tour, we decide to leave it and see what they think tomorrow. There is a huge, huge spider above the pool (Darth Vader) and several around our hut (harvey, harold and twinkle toes). That night whilst drinking and chatting to other people who share our hut, a huge snake comes out of the jungle and makes its way across the patio. The other people where a English journalist student and a hardcore techno DJ. There seems to be a lot of in debt students around travelling. I think they might have a life of repayment in front of them, We also see toads jumping around. There are heavy noises out in the woods, who knows what they could be.

The next day we decide to walk to a water hole, which is basically a stream that you can swim in. That means no crocs and no jellyfish. Its a hard walk along the road in the hot weather. By the time we get there we are ready to be cool. However the water is quiet cold and shaded. We get in though. There a few Spanish girls swimming there and an English family.

Then Jonah and his mum turn up and start to feed the hidden fish, this also attracts eels. Eels are not shy and one bites Jonah. Not hard but enough to freak us out a bit, one goes for Mick and he splashes around to avoid it. We keep out the water after this and after a quick visit to the bottle shop we hike back. We make the mistake of trying the beach walk home but the tide is in and we have to turn back.

By the time we make it back to the beach house, we are ready to jump in the pool again. We also see a weird lizard running down the path on his hind legs, very strange like something off eXistenZ. We meet a English girl that is very freaked out after she stepped over a dangerous snake. Day seem to go by like this until we leave for Port Douglas.

It's the day before Claire's birthday and we wake up early to get the bus to the habitat and to have breakfast with the birds. The food is great, load of weird tropical fruit and a bunch of fried food as well. The place was great, feeding kangaroos and stroking emu and crocs. Spent the whole day there, it was a right laugh. I don't really like zoo's, I see them as a prison, but this place took in injured animals and the people who work there where very into what they where doing.

Then back to Port Douglas and the bus back to Cairns. We count our mosquito bites Mick a total of 11 Claire left foot 4, left arm 5 left leg 4, sides 2 back 13 clearly my right side is much more attractive than my left. Right arm 18 right foot 20 amounting to grand total of 73 itchy pussy wounds yum. Mick obviously must taste bitter.  We check in to a hostel and hit the sack as we have an early rise to go to the great barrier reef on Claire's birthday. We wake, get tagged and herded to the boat and out we go. We arrive at Michaelmas Cay, which is a bird sanctuary and alive with squawking. After a quick snorkel lesson, we are chasing colourful fish around different coral structures and past huge giant clams. Amazing. Then we get back eat a Thai meal and have a drink or two. The next day is Australian day, but we don't do much but chill in the shade in the park. Thanks for the birthday emails guys they meant a lot being the other side of the world and all. Gooday.

title: Bloody Spiders it's bears birthday! Extra films...
Mumbai MIx
description: Thirteen hour flight we slide back into he northern hemisphere and bang we arrive in India. The hubbub and the chaos hits us immediately, but before you know it we are squeezed into an air conditioned taxi and we are hurtling through the streets of Mumbai.

We drive through some of the slums and we knew their would be poverty but nothing can quite prepare you for the sight of whole families under make shift shelters on the pavement. The taxi pulls up outside a dubious looking establishment. We make our way upstairs where our fears are confirmed. We carefully rap ourselves up in our sleeping bag liners. It feels like an 19th century brothel but we are still laughing, well at least for a while until our laughter and duty free cant fight off reality any more.

It's the forth day in Mumbai and the jet lag has just about gone, we are now getting up in the afternoon as normal. We have parked ourselves in the Cowes, a hotel in the Colaba area, not far from the bay. The hotel is over staffed and under maintained. The area is. The drains are. The ravens and sleeping dogs, the shitty dust where the pavement has been broken up will help to break your nerve. The women with the monkey on the leach or the blind man stamping his staff might help. There's always the old man deeply lost in religion with a weird chant and an instrument that is like two metal flat sticks and some sort of semi circle clasp at the bottom: Twang, twang, mantra, mantra, until a waiter at Leopolds (open since 1871) ushers him away.

There is a drawer in our room with a bunch of letters to the same person. Claire reckons it was the now dead previous tenet. We are on a side road off the main drag. The horn is used so you don't get run over, which would be easy to achieve. As would buying a giant balloon, bongo drums, peacock feather fans, Krishna mints and hash. As you know I used to live the Netherlands, didn't smoke hash then and it was semi-legal there.
We missed the end of one Mumbai festival, but that's OK as another one has started. We watched

Tibetan dancing whilst following a city walk from the guide book. Bewildering city, Don't take any pictures of government buildings or they will have you. It's ok to take photo's of the gateway to India, where the British left. We walked around a park where there must have been at least a 100 cricket matches going off. We walked into the reservation centre to book a train to Goa, but it was worse than the website that doesn't take Visa. It's like a crazy housing benefit office. Hundreds of people in about 10 queues all shuffling and yearning, all clutching pages of bureaucrazy.
We gave up and booked an overnight A/C bus instead, we may get the train back.
There is a lot of colour here though. Layers of colour. In the sari's, in the paintings, especially in the food and in the flavour's of the food. I came here to get fat.

title: The missing elephant, the monkeys and the rat
description: Well my pirated copy of  book is strangely close to where we are at. He mentions Leopold, the café where we did most of initial eating and drinking. I picked this copy up off a street vendor, I had a go at bartering and ended up short changed and with a photocopied version. Oh well, it does the job and it only cost Rp 160 (about 2 English quid).

Our mission that day was to get off the island of Mumbai and go across the toxic waters to Elephanta island. We woke, I failed to get curry for breakfast, but did scoff two somosa. Mumbai seems to wake up late, so if you are dodging around at 9am, you will only get a few hellos rather than a pitch. Although the boat touts do pitch and before we know it we are on a very rocky tub of a boat, shouting and slurping our way through the hazy crowded harbour. Dropping off shopping and people on other boats as we went.

Most people in India are Hindu. Hindu is vast, complicated and full of destroyers, creators, cosmic dancers, sects, carnations, castes and and and a lot of stuff. It's as old as the hills and often has huge statues of multi-armed deities carved out in the hills. As we saw on Elephanta. Why is it called Elephanta? Well the British followed the Portuguese's naming. Still not clear? Well it used to have a great stone elephant. However it sort of fell down, so they moved it to Victoria park in Mumbai.

Elephanta has scenes carved out of the rock devoted to the activities of the Saivism sect of Hinduism and not Vaishnavism as you might have thought. No it's Shiva the great destroyer in many different carnations all carved out in the 7th Century.

Lots of cheeky monkeys, dogs and the odd raven as well occupy the island. Also there is a new charge around every corner with the last one being the most unexpected and painful. However, you can also pick up a dam tasty corn on the cob, char grilled for 12p. Not a bad trip and we met a bloke form Honolulu, that we had met in the middle of nowhere on the Kilatoa loop, way back in Ecuador.

I remember we where waiting for a bus on a dusty road. No bus stop, just faith that the bus would turn up and it did, we squeezed on board with our rucksacks and found some seats at the back. They where the only other western people on the bus. A real travellers moment. He, Jason, had been home and is now back travelling again.
We de-boated clambering through a few boats and headed back thought the chaos back to our stagnant hotel.

I had a bad nightmare about myself and Mick living in squallier in India, or could it have been Nottingham? I'm not sure, but I can remember thinking as I wearily stepped out of bed to go to the toilet: At least I haven't seen any rats . Hay presto as I put my hand on the light switch I feel I thud against my hip and something slide down my leg. I
convince myself I just trod on my PJ bottoms but I suddenly see the little critter pop out from behind the furniture. It had clearly used my leg as a fireman's pole.
It was passed midnight but I had to pack all our clothes in case the rat chose our clothes for a bed or
