a toilet. The next day I decide that I didn't want to be a traveller any more. Just for one day I would like to be transported home to see friends and family to have a hot bath and clean sheets. (as I now believe my bites have been caused by bed bugs not mosquitoes. Oh well.

Curry for breakfast after check out and bag storage and then a taxi to toxic beach. After a sit taking in the quiet it was time for the game of dodging traffic and the shrill of their horns to get to Mani Bhavan or Gandi's Mumbai pad.

We saw his letter to Hitler (which starts off dear friend, Gandi was in league with Hitler! Put that in your propaganda model and smoke it!) and photo with Charlie Chaplin. After getting ripped off by crap taxi man and just the heat and hectic streets of Mumbai grinding us down we head back to our side of town for some good Lebanese food and then the bus hunt began. The bus will be the only bus near the Metro Cinema. Lies, lies, lies. Politeness gets in the way of truth here. We did find the bus eventually and the sleeper bus, is just that A/C bed compartments on a bus. Great.

We sleep on and off and experience weird motion sickness when we get to the city of Panaji in Goa. We get off the bus, it's morning and we are dazed, an Israeli who lived in Newcastle/London helps get our bags from under the bus and then we get a taxi to the hotel. I'm prying that it's a good one after the last couple of days we need a break. It's better and cheaper. Very good indeed, old Portuguese's building, mosaic bathroom, wooden four poster and hot shower! Hooraah!

title: Hot Hampi
description: Well Panaji is a nice enough place, but doesn't there's not a load to do. Viva Panaji is a cool place to eat and down a few kingfisher and our hotel was great, but we came to leave. Of course this was a last minute panic and scramble around a dark dusty bus park. We met a Swedish couple and before knew it there was a crowd of us waiting for the bus to Hampi.

The 9 hour bus journey turned into 14, but wasn't really that bad. Soon we were on a tuktuk bombing through the dusty village, past the snake charmers, monkeys and cows with huge horns to our basic room. This town is surrounded by huge red rocks and has a hell of lot of weird temple things.

Vicky's is where we are staying and his family runs the guest house. It has a roof top café where you can see cows, people's wanderings and people going about their day-to-day washing, sewing etc. We even witnessed a heated exchange of shoves and shouts. Eventually stopped by one women in a blue sari.

This is a dry town. No booze, anywhere, well apart from the government run hotel/bar. Ragoo is our rickshaw driver. His History and Economic education didn't help him get a job, so with a bank loan he got a rickshaw, he didn't want to break himself in the banana plantation like his father. His family follow baba part of Hindu and he has a sticker to prove this in the front of his rickshaw. He speaks many languages, one to his family, one to his mates, English to us. He spends the day showing us around the hundreds of temples. He will marry someone picked for him in two years time

It's hot though and its hard to hold interest, although the stone carvings are impressive. We wander through the vast stone city scape getting drunk by the sun and trying to find the columns that let out a musical tune if you tap them. There's squirrels moving as fast as lizards and monkeys rooting through a family's picnic bag as they look on laughing.

India is full of subtleties but its not subtle. I can see how people could become addicted to visiting here, in the way they like a drug that doesn't make them feel good a lot of the time. The last three beds have been a bit too small for me and I'm hardly tall, the power cuts out randomly here and the fan stops in the cell of a room we are renting. It gets hot quickly. We might have to invest in another copy of

Shantaram as we both now are reading it. We will be reading it tonight as we are back on a sleeper bus and heading for the Goa coast again, leaving the great temples and the well cooked potatoes at Vickys.

comments.author: carol
content: I remember hampi, decorative things out side doors like door mats but not, and big bounlders in the river that i thought should have been elephants! Monkeys nipping in windows and nicking stuff. Jolly good, keep up the good work! we stayed in Benoulim in goa. bet its changed alot in 10 years. Is it Panjim where the big market is? xxx

comments.author: Mum
content: What was Carol doing writing to you at 11.37 pm on Valentine's Day?
It doesn't sound quite so inviting when you mention rats!

comments.author: Andreas and Karolina
content: Hello!

We are now in Varkala enjoying the beach and the cliffs. It's a great place so you have something to look forward to! We are staying at this place (that is also mentioned in that book you now...): http://www.keralabamboohouse.com/
Have fun and see you around!

title: Rachel sails down from the sky
description: So the rickshaw drivers late, ultimately this doesngt matter as the bus has many complications before it leaves. Away from Hampi. A few things I missed out about Hampi: The bell pepper stealing monkey, which explains itself and the four o clock explosion. The rickshaw driver tells us that the distant explosion is from an Iron Ore mine, just out side the near by town. He also tells us children work in the mine. Ugly. But we are away on the sleeper, it's got bigger beds and a sliding door of privacy.

Early in the morning we shake our selves and fall out the bus to five people wanting our rickshaw custom. We get one to the beach and after a few samples of different hotels we pick one in this rough beach village. The rooms expensive and a bit rubbish, but so much better than Hampi. It has hot water and is huge. We go out in search of curry. Scruffy little beach with people floating around in the air. The whole day is the usual daze after a sleeper ride and we soon are flicking through the channels as  our consciousness fades.

The next day is Rigley's birthday. What does this mean. It means its valentine day. We move rooms which has a bath! But no hot water. We spend the day by the pool and then purchasing blankiephant (a sheet with elephants on). We watched the sun melt into the sea whilst eating more curry and drinking a kingfisher or two.

To the airport to meet Rachel. The Goa airport, which originally and still is a military airport. All is confusion and you cangt get into the airport. We where early and the plane was late. Three  hours later and we where getting our pre-paid taxi to Anjuna.

Hello! it is I rachel, making my brief (well I will try my best) appearance on this blog to tell you of my experiences of my trip from mumbai to kerralla and of the experiences I have gained on meeting these two nutters out here!

Where to start? well, I write this from the bathroom of our above average accommodation in kerralla. That is something compared with the  bathrooms I have seen during the journey so far as they have not been ones I have wished to spend time in, however, we have been blessed to find this room and clean bathroom in amongst the madness we have experienced so far. And to say that I am sat here now typing away whist Claire and Mick sleep is really something. This is a real rarity, a luxury, a bathroom which has seen bleach and such a departure from some of the harrowing things I have seen so far!  If I told you that I had seen shit seeping out of one of the airplane toilet doors coming here you probably wouldngt believe me, but sadly that was the truth and unlucky for me, my seat was just too close to the devastation. Mental note, dongt always go for the cheapest flight out there..

Moving on, from there!! swiftly does it, the plane gets into Mumbai, then I've to catch another to goa which is only 3 hours delayed, something to do with the airline company had not booked the landing space and some Indian guy also telling me that the Indian airforce may also be using the run way!! Either way it was hassle and upon arrival to Mumbai money was not forthcoming from the ATM machine but all was resolved by a nice Indian guy working in the airport who ever so trustingly lent me some money!! 1000 rupees as well! By god, I reckon I'd deserved that karma and it was a really good welcome to India. After that positive experience I eventually caught my flight to goa and got to meet the two nomads and begin the adventure..

Wow! some long taxi ride eventually got us to Anduna in goa, praise the lord!, we found accommodation easily complete with air conditioning , TV! and a maroon bath tub. I mean, what more could a girl ask for. Oh and the best curry later on that night for less than £3.50, I really was content, oh and in a pretty fairy lit garden too with one, two a few kingfisher beers and then a bottle of carry out bacardi things became increasingly drunker.

Highlight of that night has probably got to be when we managed to lock ourselves out on our hotel room balcony, closing the double doors in attempt to stop the mosquitoes from invading, was probably not one of our better ideas as it also prevented us from getting back into the room! and left us at the mercy of the bloody mosquitoes.  Luckily we managed to call for help and all in good time, a bemused member of hotel staff opened the doors again, and then we continued to drink.. Chips were purchased that night and nurafen was taken and we woke up not in the best health the next day but we did manage to get some sunbathing in which I thought was pretty impressive and hardcore.

The next few days in Anduna for me were about sunbathing, cows on the beach and a really aggressive shop keeper woman demanding us to buy saris from her shop, oh and lots of lovely sea views and good curries at sunset. What a beautiful place, so many cows everywhere and scraggy mangy dogs who werengt so lovable. Oh and the night market on Saturday night, loads of bargains to be had an counterfeit sunglasses for the (sh)it girl here. Think we all did well that night, Mick has had a Bruce lee t shirt which has gone down well with the locals and Claire bought some fishermen pants and a dress for next to nothing. What a load of bargains! I say, much more economical to spend out here than in Primark.  Anyway, those are the nice bits of the blog. Oh and there's a visit to the spice farm, I'll mention just briefly before I go on about the train experience. For around three quid entrance fee, we got to see lots of different spices and fruits growing out on a plantation, and learnt loads of interesting facts like its dead difficult to grow cashew nuts, it grows off a fruit which is inedible and they have to roast it to detach the cashew and not so many grow on a tree. You also only get 250 narnas to an average banana tree, once the bananas are picked, the tree then gets cut and starts growing somewhere else, they call it the walking tree blah blah blah, you still reading ?. Well, we thought it was interesting anyway and the curry buffet was damned good.

Ok, the train journey to kerrala, what can I say, not orient express more like urine express. Seemed such a romantic idea to catch the train down the coast to kerrala, to share a cabin and watch the sunrise etc. Well, the reality of that was more of a moving prison cell complete with Bridewell style beds which we shared with three other men all within too close proximity! This was after spending almost 6 hours waiting in this station where drinking on the station was prohibited and the men were naturally mesmorised by mine and claires' beauty and good looks, to a point of uncomfort felt by all of us. Still, there was a little cute puppy running around the station, trying to play with an older scraggy dog I affectionately named 'one ear' (well actually had two but one was up, the other down) To get back to the story, the deformed dog seemed to play along with cute puppy and provided us with a good hours worth of time killing activity. Then there was the pub, erm the pub, what can I say. Quite a distinctive bathroom which will no doubt feature in the pictures complete with 2 dozen eggs freshly stored within close proximity of the toilet. Thank fuck we didngt order omelette!

Anyway, thanks to the wonders of diazepam and time which eventually passed we got off that nasty train and started the  next part of our journey in kerrala, which I will now leave to mick to tell you all about. Glad we got there in the end though. It has taken me ages to write this, two hours, and eight minutes to be exact! Hope your still with us on the old narrative.. See you! rachxxxx

Kerala elected CPI communist party. Is this why people where motor cycle helmets here? Why there are a million school children everywhere (98% literacy here)? Why there is high suicide rate and government ran bottle shops? Where the people in the queue feel uncomfortable that we are queuing as we are their guests and we feel uncomfortable jumping the queue so we dongt. Also all the open air restaurants serve beer in tea pots and mugs. There are Muslims, Janes, Jews, Christians and Hindus all living together here. We met a Muslim rickshaw driver and he took us all around Fort Cochin. We ignored many a temple and church, synagogue and one navel museum. We couldngt ignore the snake charmer, the chained elephants in some sort of Hindu festival and the ginger processing room. They rang the bell again and again and then a huge explosion. Before we knew it we were in a taxi again heading to house boat central and  it is rated in the top 10 things to do before you die in the often wrong lonely planet.

comments.author: Mum
content: You went on a TRAIN and didn't take any photos?

comments.author: rachel
content: Oh message to micks mum, that grey/dreary photo of some fans was the train photo. That was about the highlight of the 'on the train' expereince! ...

Anyway, hey guys i dont know how to work this thing, i know i am replying to myself but im hoping you get the message somehow! well well, where the hell are you guys now then? Hopefully you are both well and on your way up to the dreaded not mentioned place!

Well is survived trivandum. It was fucking fantastic! BY the second day i was out without my headscalf and realising all was safe and really really friendly. Now im in kovulum beach which is not quite karkala but no the less has some nice features like a lighthouse, i wanted to climb today but was  closed but a lovely view of the sunset and a really nice beach 3 km away which i am moving lodgings to tomorrow. Get this, room with tv, refridgerator, balcony, 1,500 i figured i will treat myself as the place i have been satying in has been really shitty and plus i will have a night of uncomfort on the night bus to pondicherry on tues. Hopefully im off to that place in tamil nadu tomorrow to watch sunset, supposed to be most southern point of india, but shall have to see if everything goes to plan and taxi driver is willing! So thats about if from me. I am really happy today, had a really nice day. Do miss you two very much though and have thought there has been so many nice moments i would ahve loved to have shared with you. anway, i must go now but big hug and kiss to you both and hope the dreaded M place is a passing through episode!!
lots of love to me and to you and you!!! xxxxxxxxxxxxx

title: A holiday in a holiday
description: The wonderful memories of the house boat trip were fading quickly in hectic roads of Alappuzha. I had developed a cold, which I generously would share with Claire. Rachel fell in love with This is England film that we watched on the laptop but it didn't stop her toilet trips. We all couldn't sleep. The hidden grimness of the hostel was moving in. We needed to leave. Let's get the first bus out of here! Or Taxi. We arranged with the slimy hostel owner (Stampy) a taxi out of there and on to the next town, which was a cliff and beach resort.

Varkalam is where we got to and bamboo haven. Shiva (the great destroyer) is the lad that is helping us out and he's great laugh. All is good with the world. We quickly got in a routine of playing with the huge waves in the Lakshadweep Sea and then letting the sun evaporate the water off. We fell into our books (well the one book Shantaram that we are sharing chapter by chapter) and the singing of the ananas women on the beach. Watch out for the dog packs though. Enjoy the view of great Indian coast line (ignore the rubbish, mostly plastic dumped here and there). Walk from the stalls down by the pissy or minty steps. Past the laid out washing drying on the rocks.

None of the bars here have licences, so when you buy a beer, they serve it in a mug and you keep the bottle under the table. They do have fresh dead fish outside the restaurants, usually including a huge sword fish, which I bet would have looked great alive. A bottle of wine costs. All booze costs, unless you go to a liquor store. Best not go at night, like we did. Rickshaw across town. It's down that dark and dusty alley, you have to squeeze past that truck, the driver indicated. Past the truck was a bared building

front and counter. Men dotted about everywhere in the shadows and lined up next to a barb wired fence to counter. Claire was not covered up really not the best move. There where no other women here. There were only worn and hard looking Indians. The queue moved slowly. We hid in the shadows.Two bottles of your best rum please.. Yes thanks, thanks thanks. Back to the safety of the rickshaw and back to the coast.

Rachel has less time than us here, so must plan. A bit of a frantic back and forth decisions and she has arranged a route to the next town and bunch of adventures. Pondicherry has Rachel's curiosity after featuring in a book she has read, so she aims herself for there. But before she leaves she buys more and more clothes. Some of the pictures in the hostel make a good back drop for a photo shoot. As for us two, we are sneezing and confused. The mighty Karl is turning up in Mumbai next week and we are miles away. After a day or two trying to get our
thoughts together, we just book a flight back to the crushing, biting town of Mumbai. Then we will head north with Karl to a fairy tail palace in Udaipur.

Although first we are going to have a holiday here and it's all wake up late, ignore the temples visits, jump in the sea and have a good curry and some rum before sleep brings us around to start it all over again. This is ferris wheel living.

comments.author: Mum
content: Lovely sunsets - but it sounds a bit scary in parts.  Is India wonderful or a nightmare?

comments.author: claire
content: both. I'd describe it as a love hate relationship

title: The Karl Connection
description: The days of beach reading and discussion of sea monsters, sand shelves, different types of drag and wave are gone. The days where we did Indian cookery classes are past. Claire's redundant yoga lesson, rum nights and late mornings have all dried up. We where back in a taxi heading to the airport. Mumbai domestic airport is so much better than the international one, but outside we are still confused and the two fold rip off taxi driver dodgers us around the sprawl of the screeching city.

All this fades as we meet the pail and calm face of Karl. Soon we are raising our glasses and filling our faces. We buy a copy of Shantaram and shove it Karl's hands, although he soon gets the sickness and we are haggling with a chemist to put him right. A day of waiting and then we take a two hour taxi drive across the city to a lesser train station. Its rush hour (8pm) and normally this would take 30 minutes. Super crazy traffic compete for space. All beeping all jerking back and forth. Motorbikes with women in bright saris sitting side saddle, taxis filled to the brim with oversized men.

We get there. It's dark and the little light sends long shadows over the people sitting on the dusty pavement and the children selling padlocks and chains for your luggage, although they are really selling paranoia. We stock up on snacks, in the aircraft hanger of the station waiting room, complete with rooms for women, enquiries, toilets, police and everything you could want. People sit in the middle of the space on blankets with there goods covered up with rugs.

We head to our platform and walk down the edge of the dusty blue train. The economical class is a dark carriage with bars, an old women freaks me out as she appears out of the dark as we walk past. We soon find our beds although we are not all together which sucks, but on the whole the train journey was good and we eat the cooked dinner on the train, although Claire didn't like the Thai. I did and think so did Karl.

We lent our India book to a man on the train and he returned the favour by helping us negotiate a taxi to the town of Erotic temples  Khajuraho. We get to the Zen hotel and have a few beers, some crap food and soon we are sleeping. Next day we spend most of it looking around the wonders of the Hindu temples and then drinking and eating in a tree house. Then it's a tiger safari and on to Varanasi but you have to wait until next time for that.....

title: Mind the Ghat
description: The world never looks good at 5am, but the cold air as we bump around in the back of a jeep to Panna National Park wakes us up somewhat.  We collect a guide who does an excellent job of pointing to things that are 'natural' and almost immediately spot a family of peacocks, followed by monkeys (both cheeky and non-cheek varieties), antelope, samba, spotted deer and a solitary crocodile.  The tiger hunt was less of a success though, so the spot in front of the fire will have to remain bare a little longer.  Such an early start requires an lot of recuperation, (as does a lot of suspect curry), so it was back to the hotel to take it easy and wait for the journey to Varanasi where it required an impressive 8 people to helps us carry our own bags to the car.
Excuse please, duck.
Sorry?
Down, down, now please.

So we put our heads between our legs and prepare to kiss our wallets goodbye.  And that's how we passed thorough most of the wild west style towns along the way.  It's strange how a pleasant night drive through the country side can turn more than a little bit sinister when the driver tells you you're in 'very dangerous area'.
You mean tigers?
No.
Snakes?
No, criminal.  They stop car, they take moneys, they kill.
Lovely, thanks.

His previously smooth driving became a lot more urgent and erratic as he sped down the tiny road, hardly slowing as he dived into the dirt to avoid the occasional oncoming truck.  It clearly wasn't something he told the dumb tourists just for entertainment.  What few motorcyclists there are in the area carry rifles for protection.  Indian ingenuity must have been at it's peek when some genius decided the best material for a railway crossing was gravel, and we immediately got stuck on the tracks.  Spinning the wheels only dug us in deeper & in the cloud covered night we could only see about 50 meters down the track on either side.  The driver was clearly starting to panic so we  jumped out to push.  It's amazing how much the threat of bandits and high speeds trains works to concentrate the mind & we were out of the track & back in the car within seconds. We completed the two hour journey in a hectic hour and a quarter.  We looked at each other as we grabbed ouR bags from the roof & agreed that it was all 'Fucking cool!' I don't think the driver was looking forward to the journey back though.

Mohaba train station is everything a good frontier station should be.  Crumbling, chaotic and populated by wild looking people from surrounding villages and beyond.  Almost every available space on the ground was occupied by sleeping bodies, and those still awake stood and stared as the European tourists  tried their best to act casual.  Combined with the journey there, it seemed a very sinister place to us.  We found a second class waiting room to hide in where a travelling preacher asked after our everlasting souls.  He also explained that the danger in the area was due to the fact that the police in the Indian states generally don't cooperate, and so criminals on the run often cross the border into the neighbouring state to avoid the police Dukes of Hazzard style.   A gruff two star general appeared and barked that we put our bags standing in the corner and ordered that we were not to sleep.  'Very dangerous here' he said, prodding the other sleepers who remained awake for as long as it took him to leave & then turned over and went back to sleep.  We got the impression that he's not used to polite conversation.  When the huge train arrived about two hours later there was a mild panic was we ran up and down the platform trying to find our carriage before the train took off again.  Giving up we clambered up into the nearest door only to find it was our carriage.  We climbed into our berths, and  were asleep within seconds (except for Mick who has some essential Linux reading to do first).

The touts in Varanasi don't waste much time, and our feet had barely hit the platform the next morning when one attached himself to us.  He invited himself into our taxi but jumped out a few minutes later, clearly not pleased to discover we'd already booked a hotel and there wasn't gong to be any commission in it for him.  The streets of this city seem even more chaotic than the average Indian city and our hassle gauges were already well into the red when we detached ourselves from the limpet-like, driver (I show you better hotel) and walked into the Palace on the Ganges hotel.  After some confusion it transpires that we actually have a booking in the Palace on the River hotel a few kilometres away.  The easiest way to get there we're told, is by boat.  So after another full frontal assault from the taxi driver who's still waiting outside we brace ourselves and begin the haggling with the red-eyed bettle chewing man on the river bank.  Once we make the deal it's all red-toothed smiles and our boat pulls up beside a group of women washing and wailing in the Ganges.  The boatman tells us they're a funeral party.  They apply a pink paint to themselves during the funeral ceremony and wash it off 10 days later.

We climb aboard and suddenly the spirit of the river seems to hit us and what was a stressful, messy affair becomes a slow and tranquil journey upstream.  The chaos of the city is nowhere to be seen on the Ganges as people wash, pray, talk and laugh on the steps or ghats that lead down to the water.  After about twenty minutes of rowing we pull in along some women washing clothes and climb the steps to the hotel.  We're greeted by garlands of roses and cool drinks before being shown to our rooms and then heading straight to the restaurant on the top floor for good food and great views of the river, the town and the monkeys leaping along the rooftops, jumping through windows and stealing bread.  Having first expected nothing but the worst from this city we easily decide to spend three nights here.

In the evening we make our way through the narrow and incredibly atmospheric backstreets and into the madness of the modern streets in search of some much deserved alcohol. A small plump man we privately christen Pabaker (a character from the novel Shantaram) shows us to a dark subterranean cage where we restock and then sweet talks us into visiting his silk factory around the corner.  Inside we sit cross-legged as Pabaker and his brother unfurl with a flourish, sheet upon sheet of embroidered silk.  We leave an hour later weighed down by feather-light silks and fight through the craziness back to our sanctuary.
Karl's Pictures can be found here....

title: Boaters, floaters and rum
description: So we left the silky man who Karl failed to mention also played Indian drums at techno parties in Goa so it was only right that he knew where to buy Hashish, MDMA and last but not least Opium we assured him that we were more than happy with just the rum. So we retired to our room for the night to get completely legless.
We are slow to get up but we manage to drag our banging heads to a German bakery. We sit cross legged on the mattress provided and we relax until we spot

a mouse then another and another scurrying over the beds near by but somewhat hardened from the rat experience and too hung over to care we took into our crappy breakfast and morning paper. The Times of Indian tells of a gang that held 17 people to sell there blood and 10 year old girl getting burnt to death by 10 year old boys... erm nice.

Finally more together we take an early evening stroll along the Ghats until we come to the funeral Ghat. We are assured that travellers are welcome as long as we refrain from taking photos. We approach the funeral fire somewhat apprehensively but we are soon greeted by a local man who ushers us closer to the fires and explains the intricacies of the ceremony. The man runs a house for those older people that come to Varansi before to die. It is believed that if they are cremated next to the Ganges then they will go straight to Heaven rather than being reincarnated. He leads us to a position that is directly in front of a roaring cremation and a platform of wood where body is about to be put in place for the beginning of the ceremony.

The body is first placed in the Ganges on a bamboo stretcher to be cleansed then the vibrant cloth that covers the body are removed one by one. The body is then placed by on top of the wood by male family members the head faces heaven and the feet toward the water. The eldest son has completely shaved his body apart from on small piece of hair on the back of his head. He then circles the fire five times to represent the elements and then sets fire to the wood. When only embers remain the eldest son fills

a clay pot from the Ganges and put the fire out . With his back toward the fire he throws the pot over his head so it smashes and he walks away not looking back. This is to represent the breaking of emotional ties to this world allowing the soul to pass safely to heaven. Any bone left over are then collected and thrown into the Ganges. Any family member that starts to cry must leave the ceremony as this also impedes the souls safe passage. The ceremony is incredibly respectful and we are all deeply moved by the experience.

This is a very industrious process with at least 10 going off in different stages when we where there. The wood used is brought in for its burning properties from far a way and is very expensive. There are from 100 to 200 a day and people from all over the world. Apparently a French bloke got burnt there last week.

Very hot and a little sprinkled in ash we decide to take a boat ride at sun set and to witness the Puja from the calmness of the Ganges. We slip through the velvety water and although the water is littered with many tourists maintains it dignity and serenity. We all light candles on a bed of flowers, think of our families happiness and heath and release them.

We rise at 5.30 am and after checking in with each other about our morning toilet motions and take to the water for a truly glorious sun rise. As we return to our Ghat we see a large object floating in the water. As we get closer we realise that it strangely resembles a body. Oh yes it is a body. Karl gently nudges the boats man narrowly missing a full on collision with Floating Freddy as Karl respectfully refers to him. We soon notice that are three crows on his back that are kindly assisting Floating Freddy to loose those extra pounds. After spending a few hours in a small hot office trying to arrange our exit from Varanasi we have a couple of beers served in silver goblets and coffee pots and then to bed.
Another early start and we are off to the train station for the usual panicky faff before catching the train. We are all in separate carbines and discover the express train
will take seven hours longer then we were told by the tour agent that ripped us off. I soon retire to my bed that I affectionately refer to as the refrigerated coffin. Nice.

title: Ones we Forghat...
description: Ooops, missed out some photos, so here they are...
Also you can see some photos of things to come at

title: Romantic Ego
description: The train chugged along, the bloke opposite me scowled (perhaps because we gave away his sheets when we thought he'd left) and bought anything that was on offer. Claire and I took it in turns to finish of  Shantaram: 20 pages left each, then 10, then 3 and done. Book-less!

We get to Japiur which we soon realise is the town where the taxi drivers do not know where to go. After much bartering, walking off and getting a better price, we get into the taxi. Although, these young lads, do not have a clue where they are going. We eventually tell them to take us back to the train station, we get our stuff out of the boot, walk off and pay them nowt.

Karl gets out his GPS things and we walk. Bare in mind this is two in the morning and there are people asleep in their rickshaws, under the overpass and we are all bagged up. Some roads have long shadows and don't look too friendly. We sit down outside a hotel and this bloke comes up to us, before we know it he has sorted a taxi whom knows our hotel and we are speeding our way to the Generals Retreat. Great place. Ran by the dead general's family. Regiment pictures on the wall, spotlessly clean and tasteful  décor. We hit the clean sheets.

Next day we have a late breakfast and plan to book a trip to Agra and the Taj Mahal. This was going to involve taxi's to travel agents, sitting around in a hot room and trying to work out the best train to take for a day trip. This was all not needed as we just got our hotel to book us a taxi all the way there and back. By far the best solution. Four hours there and four hours back, then we'll escape this big city to enjoy the Holi festival in small town  Bundi.

So we take a quick look around the walled city until Karl's stomach has us running up and down the street looking for a café or something with a toilet. Taxi! Hotel! Of course they don't know the way, but we do and Karl's cramping over. We make it in time.

Move rooms faff and we go out to eat at an Italian restaurant (owned by the same people who have one in  Khajuraho). Strange set up though: You have to walk through what's like concrete tunnels and stairs, not dissimilar to a car park. Then take the quasi freight lift to the roof top, past the huge satellite dishes and then you can enjoy a beer in a tea pot. ( special tea or pop).

Next morning we wake early and drive to Agra, stopping off on the way to see a huge mosque. The touts here are on speed, or something like and soon we are telling them lies about origins, what our names are or if we can speak English.

The mosque is quiet huge though and Claire managed not to offend strict Muslims by pointing the souls of her feet at Mecca whilst taking a picture of the ceiling. Although she did do this in the mosque at Taj Mahal. Karl also offended someone by taking a picture of turtles in the secret lake and not the  washing Ghat. Looks like it's only me going to heaven.

We get there and take a horse and cart from the car park outside the no car zone. Touts are crazy and will sell you anything from hand print kits to their very important guide service. After much arsing around, money exchanging hands, putting bags and a dangerous copy of the lonely planet in the cloak room, we walk into the entrance area.  Wow.

Made for his dead wife (it is a grave) and meant to be a copy of heaven. He didn't get to enjoy it though, as he and his concubines where locked up in the red fort after a family betrayal and spending a fortune making the Taj Mahal, with the best gems, marble and craftsmen from 1000's of miles around. However, in the red fort he could see the Taj Mahal through a window and there he died of an aphrodisiac overdose. His corpse was secretly shipped over to lie forever with his love of his life and favourite wife.

It was a very hot day, but we all felt good and soon got dozy in the taxi on the way back through the dust storms. The next day we have a random trip through some of the sights of Japiur. Including in the city palace, these huge silver 900n gallon jugs (made of coins) for transporting Ganges water to England. Soon its back to the hotel and the last night before a huge confusion at the bus station going back and forth with heavy bags until we are on our way to Bundi. The bonfires at the sides of the road where just getting lit as we left. This is the first part of the Holi festival...

title: Dye, dye, die!
description: So where we at? I'm sitting in the dark typing whilst Claire is trying to sleep off stomach problems and Karl should have just stepped off a bus in Mumbai.

Anyway back to arriving in Bundi. It's night, the bus station is empty. The Indian women Claire had met on the bus is standing there with her two brothers, we pick up our bags and walk around the corner to get a tuk-tuk. Off we speed into the night dodging fires on the way until we reach our hostel. We get settled and sleep after a bottle of rum.

The morning brings noises from the street. I look out of the window and its happening. Any person on the street is covered in dye. The streets and everyone in sight is covered in rainbows of colour. I have a quick peek out the door and even in the hall of the hostel I see people with dye on them. Unavoidable.

We soon get up and go down stairs where the people who run the hostel wish us happy Holi and place dye on our faces and hair. We re-group and head out in search of food. Karl forgets his GPS and goes back for it, in the meantime me and Claire get covered by every group or motorbike that goes by. No water pistols here, like we've seen for sale in every other town. They come up and place the dye on you. Karl joins us and we have a quick wander until some over excited boy gets out of control with Claire so we head back to the hostel and watch the monkeys and people from the window looking over the street.  By about three o'clock the excitement has dyed out and we go about the lengthy task of washing away the festival of colour.

With Holi over the next day we walk around in the heat and have look at the ruins of Bundi. We try and get bus tickets and generally get lost. After returning to the hostel to cool down before our walk to the walls at sunset.

Before you get to the city wall, a man approaches you and offers to loan you a stick for 5rp for protection against the more aggressive monkeys up the hill side. We don't get one, but we all watch the monkeys carefully as we climb.

Before we know it we are leaving the dusty blue buildings of Bundi and heading to Pushkar. This is on a regular bus and people are sitting on top of other people and all is hot and creaking. We get to Ajmer and  get a taxi with Ed a young bloke we met on the bus.

In Pushkar there are no eggs, meat, kissing or Alcohol, although there seems to be an abundance of neo hippies and freely available Bhang Lassis ( yoghurt drink containing hashish) for purely spiritual purposes you understand. There are also a lot of Israeli shops and people although the reason for this remains unknown.

As Pushka has the only Temple dedicated to Brahma Karl and I (Claire) venture inside. We are told that we have to take a flower offering and so we do and we are immediately accompanied by a not wanted or needed guide. The temple fails to impress but non the less we are encouraged to give our flowers to the priest on duty. The small somewhat grumpy man with NHS glasses swiftly snatches the flowers from us, messes them around in a bowl with the other gifts from the hundreds of people gathered and gives you back a pick and mix selection of flowers and mints that you are supposed to release into the Ghat.

Karl and I empty the bundle at the Gandi Ghat (where his ashes where thrown), The large fishes gasping for air are more than interested in the mints. At breakfast we meet a very friendly and fast moving tortuous called Qechein who begs at the breakfast tables.

As we have time to kill before we catch the midnight bus we decide to catch a camel for a two hour ride to watch the sun set. It was a lovely experience for me as I refused to have a man at the back of me so the two boys had the guides with them , Mick's being the most talkative of the two and constantly whispering in Hindi that was slightly unnerving for Mick.

On the way back we stopped to have Chi from a lovely village family who are very entertained by us. Especially by me holding their baby and the colour of my hair. Thankful for the rest we head off at a fast trot down the dark roads full of passing lorries. Great but I would strongly advise any female planning to gallop off into the sun set on a camel to wear some supportive underwear.

The midnight bus finally arrives at 1.30am. We have to move out people that are sleeping in our cabin and as we pull away it becomes painfully apparent that the bus has little if no suspension. Bouncing up out of bunks every now and again with a good understanding of every crack in the road.

We somehow reach octopussy land and the city of Udipur on schedule. We eat at the all you can eat thali restaurant (featured on Anthony Bourdain No Reservations  - S02E07 - India Rajasthan). This is where Karl must leave us to return to Amsterdam and we must plan Thailand. Five days and we also will be gone.....

title: We are in Bangkok
description: Just a quick note to say we have left the beeps (although there is a none horn day on April the 7th) and smells of Mumbai and are now in the sweet smelling, clean sheeted, smiling city of Bangkok, we have been here a day and although the jet lag has thrown our sleep patterns around, we are digging it. There is a load of films we did not post in India, and here is the first of them (filmed by Karl)....

title: I can't believe its not Buddha
description: It was not so much jet lag, but the fact that we had an early flight making us stay up all night that made us dizzy. The flight itself was only 3 and half hours and we were in a spotless airport, I wouldn't normally mention this but it sticks out after India. The roads where less congested and there wasn't a barrage of car horns.

The area we are in is tourist area. Thousands of backpacking youths from all over. It's ok though. The food, beer and accommodation is good and cheap. 13 quid for an expensive double room a night. So I go out and buy my third pair of sun glasses and third pair of flip flops.

We spend a day walking across town along the huge boulevards to look at the reclining Buddha, swim in the roof top pool and watching a small French boy burst into tears after falling in the beautiful carp pool. The touts here have nothing on Indian touts and seem to wash over us. The street food here looks good and clean, seems you can get everything, from eggs on a stick to fried insects (which the local paper says aren't very good for you  high in .histamines). The tuk-tuk drivers have a tendency to rip you off and you just can't trust the tour agents. Also in the tourist area there some dubious second-hand/stolen backpackers shoes, bags etc. Not found a book to match Shantram, although there are several about the Bangkok Hilton  the local jail. There also a huge weekend market we went to by the easy and cheap tube.

We are liking Bangkok or officially known as Krungthep mahanakhon amonratanakosin mahintara ayuthaya mahadilok popnopparat ratchathani burirom udomratchaniwet mahasathan amonpiman avatansathit sakkathattiya witsanukamprasit. Although we can't wait to see the rest of Thailand. After finding out that the buses are faster and cheaper than the trains here, we book a train. A second class sleeper to Chiang Mai. Might do a bit of trekking around the hills there, might go to a village called Pai for the water festival (although water pistols sales are 30% down on last year). Anyway our vague plan is to mess around in north Thailand for a bit, cut across to Laos, into Cambodia and then back to Thailand beachy south region. From there we make our way through Borneo, Singapore maybe, but we should end up in Bali by June. Also might visit Kuala Lumpur as I like the name.
Thanks to Judy, Lisa, Rachel and  for all your Thailand advice.

title: Wet Pai all over our face
description: A quick taxi to the wonderful Bangkok train station, its hard not to make comparisons with India. Family's on blankets on the clean floor eating Thai food. Big pictures of the Thai royal family which are everywhere in Bangkok and the rest of Thailand so far. Thailand's flag is also ubiquitous.

We hump our bags on the train, stow them next to our beds and sit down. We miss out on the Thai train food as we've eaten and even turn down a beer. Four men, all in uniform and with guns come and check our tickets. The train starts off after a few false starts. Claire wins the counting cockroach competition and the next thing we know we are asking a man in a face mask to make up our beds and we sleep. We arrive in  Chiang Mai and get a tuk-tuk to our hostel. Everything seems to be gearing up for the Thai new year water festival.

The next few days we brave the heat and look around the great city. We go to a huge night market, we where see some great artists, wooden handy crafts and lots of plastic crap.  The wooden handy crafts are really quiet good and we would have got the lot but we have to travel. We try some wonderful tofu stir fries and buy our water weapons.

We wake on the fateful day, wrap our wallet in a plastic bag, load our guns, bottle extra ammo and head on our. We dodge through the back streets, getting ambushed and ambushing, if only we had mike off spaced with us. The enemy is around every corner, hidden and waiting to pounce, we spot one cheeky kid hid in a bucket of water, Slowly we are getting drenched, its a great laugh and all done with good humour.

Eventually I learn how to use my gun properly and we can dish out some payback. We head for the main Wat (temple) where the whole water thing originated from. This is a more sombre affair and has a little market with a bigger one down the road. We head out back into the battlefield, head towards the main gate of the wall city and the river. This is where all the action is taking place.

Every hundred yard in front of the shops there is a hose pipe into a huge drum. People bucket the water on to passing Jeeps which have there own water drums and bucket back at them. Everyone gets wet. I'm quiet amazed the motorbikes and scooters don't slip and crash as the road turns into a river.

The best weapon is the bucket on a string, which can be lowered into the river and dump on the next victim. We spot a dead fish in the river, so not so sure how clean it is, but this stops noone. The best ammo is ice water. We see some huge blocks of ice knocking around and if you get hit with ice water, you know about it.

There's food stalls and everyone looks like they are having a good time. Alcohol and smoking is banned with a huge fine and prison time and all age are battling it out, some in costume, some masked, all wet.
We are soaked to the skin and make a b-line for the ms beautiful women with umbrella on bicycle competition which is amongst a bunch of completions that is going on over the festival.
As cameras and water don;t mix we didn't bring our camera out, although we did risk Claire's camera phone. But I'm sure there will be a load of photos on flickr, etc. Here's a few from the bbc.

The thing is about the water festival is that it goes on for four or five days, so it makes leaving the town with all your luggage a bit difficult. We manage to do it a dawn tuk-tuk to the bus station. We get a packed mini bus (that we reckon is the same van we had in NZ) and we head out for the motion sickness trip to the town of Pai. The roads also are very NZ like windy up and down and the forest look like cloud forest of Ecuador.

We make it to Pai and head to the hills, where we book into a wonderful hostel of teak huts surrounding a man made lake and swimming lake. It's great. The festival is going here also, so when we walk into town over the rickety bamboo bridge we have to be tooled up.

We failed to get on a cooking course in Chiang Mai and we might fail to get on one here also as time is running out, We have to get to Cambodia before the rainy season kicks in and we have to see Loas first. Not sure what border crossing we should do: dodgy boat crossing in the north or friendship bridge in the middle.... Ermm... We will see.

title: Into Laos
description: We have to say goodbye to Phats (our giant gecko that befriended and protected us during our stay) and  goodbye to Pai just as it appears to be waking up from the water festival days, oh well. We decide to pop back to Chaing Mai for one night.

Our mini bus has a French man in his 50s who was smoking a spliff and drinking whisky at 10 am and continued to do so throughout the journey. His advice to us was don't do the boat journey to Laos its terrible, its full of drunken people.

An early rise and a tuk-tuk to the bus station. Full and ordered as normal. The national anthem comes on and we all have to stand except a couple of monks which carry on sitting and looking cool in their orange robes. We get on the bus to the boarder. An easy 5 hour air conditioned but bad suspension journey. There we spend the night on the Thai boarder with a view over the mighty Makong river and the other side  Laos, which used to be Loa until the French colonials put a silent s on.

After a night of big insects and broken English, we have another early start, horrid breakfast and the ferry to Laos. It takes at the most a five minute boat ride on a motorised canoe. Of course there is the usual crossing the boarder faff. We have to get a photo taken, we have to change Bhat to American Dollars to pay for the visa, then last minute we have to find two more dollars as its Saturday and therefore overtime. Luckily we have three dollars left over from south America Hurrah! Our passports then disappear and we are left hanging around with the crowd until their randomly handed out.

We soon discover that the speed boat or the slow two day long boat are the only real options to get to Luang Prabang, We decide on the long boat as the speed boats are notoriously dangerous and require you to wear crash helmets. Tickets are purchased and we are loaded on to a van cattle style. Of course there is not enough room, so Mick and I stand up and holding on tight as we swing around on the back of the truck.

There she is, our transport for the next two days. Not as bad as we thought, we smiled at each other and buy cushions for our delicate gluteus-maximumus as we have seen every one else clutching theirs. On the boat and we are thankful that we made the purchase. The benches are hard and upright and looked as if they had been nailed together by a demented two year old. Some people are catapulted off if their fellow bencher gets up too quickly, but it provides us with entertainment as we begin our so called six our journey.

The boat trip is uncomfortable but also wonderful. There's bunch of Loas on board, including young monks in their bright orange and shaven heads, lady boys in their over the top make up and a ton of jewellery. The rest are tourist from all over, a few rowdy search and annoy women. One Belguim, one American and a bottle of whiskey. Also an older Akha guy with a guitar and mouthorgan, who plays a few songs. One apparent love song made a few of the young Loas cry.

We meet a bunch of people, but mostly keep quiet and take in the sights and the breeze from the side of the boat. When ever the boat stops the heat comes in. White sacks are loaded on and off. People get off at their villages and on we go. Often we see children playing in the river, back-flipping into the water and waving from the banks. I think we are going to like Loas.

At one point the tension of the boat rises as more sacks come on, more crates of Loas beer and we feel too full. As we start discussing rescue techniques we hunch down the river. Just before sunset the boat pulls into Pak Beng, a cool village bastardised by tourism.

It doesn't matter if you have a fan in your room or not at 10:30pm the power is cut and the village sleeps. Surprising number of children playing with plastic guns, although what do we know. We do know that America dropped tons of land mines on Loas every day for two years with out declaring war. Apparently we shouldn't talk about that.

The next day, we go down the river again past the huge jagged black rocks that must be covered in the wet session and when the river rises. Often the matriarch comes out and shouts at the passengers to get off the side of the boats as we are about to hit some white water as the river narrows. All said and done, we get there and even though it's good to get off the boat, it was a great ride, although boring at times. Although getting bored sometimes helps you to notice stuff.

comments.author: Karl
content: You spent 2 shaggin' days on that thing?  Blimey.
Laos curry details please.

comments.author: carol
content: ey up, lovely laos. we were so happy to eat bread and soft cheese! Si Pan Don is really nice and quiet, but I think youve gone north? Mate of mine is living in Bangkok. (welsh Steve from college in chatham days) Boasting sauna and pool, and inviting people to visit.. So if you go back let me know and Ill put you intouch.
Rock on.

title: Loving Laos (long time)
description: Stepping off the boat at sunset we hang around in the crowd as they bring out our bags from underneath the floor borders of the boat. We march up the hill to the tuk tuk gathering. With a hostel address in mind we hump our stuff on to the tuk tuk. He drives us around the city and to our hostel which is about 5 minutes from where we left, no wonder he wanted paying up front. Oh well we have millions of kip in our pockets. Kip has got to be the most annoying currency we have come across, often having two numbers on the notes and the exchange rate to pounds is something dumb like 17200 to a pound. Just to make it more confusing Laos also trade in dollars and Baht as well as kip. Often we have found our selves at the point of sale dripping with sweat nervously trying to make sense of the money. This doesn't matter though as the Loas people are wonderful. Even the language seems homely - hello sounds like Zebadie (Sabai dee) - a magic roundabout of tropical heat and old French buildings.

It feels like we have been on the move for ever and we are glad of some stillness. We watch the sunset turn the sky red and tuck into some great tofu sir fry in the cheapest river side restaurant. The bugs are out in force but so are the lizards.
The next day we explore this great town followed by a massage and some great nosh. Life feels good, we drink in the night.

We wake and check into a cheaper hotel and then hire a tuk tuk for the day to take us to the waterfalls. It takes about an hour to get their, we pick up some old village women on the way and drop them off again. We pass a pair of working village elephants, wet muddy water buffalo and get to the park.

It seems like there is some heavy logging going off here as the apparent woodpeckers make a noise not unlike a circler saw. We head into the park and first see the moon beers who's lives have been saved in this sanctuary. As is an apparent tiger, who is no where to be seen. I think all tigers are invisible to us. Anyway on to the waterfalls and wow, they are idealic, The water crashes down into a bunch of turquoise swimming pool dotted up the jungle hill side.

The game is to find the best pool to swim in. We have inside knowledge that it's best to go up the left path. Soon we are sweating like crazy and just getting fed up of trying to find the ideal pool. We head back down to the assigned swimming area and dive in. Freezing cold water, but great all the same, even the little fish nibbling at your legs don't bother us, everyone seems to be having fun.

We dry off and go and see the bears again before returning home with our smiling tuk tuk driver. That night we meet up with a bloke from Leeds, his VJ partner, an Irish women and English women for a big night out. Drunken tuk tuks all over town ending up in weird Laos club with a band playing to an empty dance floor and then on to the bowling alley, the only place in town that breaks the curfew. The curfew starts at midnight, we were banging on our hotel door at 3am  opps. Great night, have few details.

title: Horizontal
description: It seems that Laos has taken
a hold of us as we don't wake up until 1.30pm

and we only make it out for breakfast at 3.30pm. After the food that returns our magic powers we muster enough energy to drag ourselves up the 300 or so steps up to the Wat for sunset. The view over Lang pan bang are certainly worth it and
a small crowed gathers to share the view.
Whilst at the Wat we see a giant moth incredibly huge . Its wing span must have been the best part of a foot.

Off to the nightmarket where Mick manages to stay calm as I mozzie amongst the lanes of textiles and jewellery. We find a wonderful stall to eat, a vegetarian Laos buffet , you fill your plate to the brim with a variety of local dishes that cost 5000 kip (that's 29p to you and me).

Later as we are out enjoying Laos Beer the sky lights up and the heavens open and we are guided into the internet café. The entertainment is provided by the five lizards devouring the local huge flying ants. As the rain dies down the ants come out in force, hundreds of the things everywhere. When we get back to our guest house the ants are trying to take over but the locals are running around catching them and throwing them into large bowls where they meet their watery death. The owner of the gust house informs me that you can buy the ants fried at the local market and they taste a little like coconut, yum.
Again we have another lazy morning and we simply wake up and wander the streets everywhere we go there are abundance of local people sleeping as they are working. I love Laos.

On the way back to the guest house we stumble across a stall where you can buy a shot of the local brew from huge glass jars, namely whisky with pickled cobras in it. Even me and Mick wont drink that particular beverage.

title: Capital Slump
description: We feel like we are wasting time but it is so beautiful here it it easy to be drawn in, but we manage to wave good bye to Luang Prabang and get the (not so) VIP bus to Vientiane.

The scenery is stunning. Endless green rolling mountains. Nine hours later, after much dozing, taking pictures out the window and stopping off for complimentary gruel where we decide to skip the battered chicken heads and we arrive in the Capital. We jump in a sawngthaew, which is like tuk tuk van thing with two seats opposite each other, managing to avoid treading on the five or so chickens squeezed into a weaved cage.

After finding a superb hotel we kick back. This city is desolate and a bit grim. Yes there is an arc de triumph and huge boulevards, but it just all seems a bit lacking. There's a huge aerobic session that pumps out bad music before sunset near the almost dry river. Also there is Laos icon: The very gold Pha That Luang, but the heat slows everything down and we just want to leave.

We are currently stuck in a planning quagmire of visa's, buses and planes. We are going to head out to Paske on Monday after we get our visa's and hopefully get down to Si Phan Don as soon as possible

title: Icons of the Mekong
description: We find the sticky fingers, full moon café and suddenly Vientiane seems better, we decide just to get our visa on the border and book a trip to Si Phan Don. We leave the luxury of our hotel and head out to Paske by bus. The sleeper bus was a tight squeeze with no curtains but a strange super hero type film featuring a Hilda Ogdan type hero who had a super scream and a cigarette constantly hanging out the corner of her mouth. Time for sleep but we seemed to have the only non stop speaker blearing out Laos popular music throughout the night Lucky us !

Once there we get a bus to the shore to get a boat to Don Khong, We are joined by a young English couple, that we have been bumping into along the way. Louisa is an 18 year old rada applicant whom seems to be very well travelled. Ross is a 20 year old ministry house DJ doing business and finance. We have a chin wag and some very good Pad Thai and steamed fish. The next day they move on to the next islands and we decide to hire cycles.

The rain hit hard all night. Is this the start of the rainy season? I hope not, Cambodia is not meant to work not so well once the rain falls. In fact, Cambodia is meant to look like a big puddle from the air once rainy season is in full affect. We watch the water bucket down whilst munching our eggs and bread breakfast. All this water puts our plan of cycling around the island to rest. It's so much cooler today, we sit around and read.

Then the rain pitiers out, we grab a pair of cycles and head north. Past small villages with a hundred Sabaidee, past sleepy dogs, past multiple schools, some wats all on the paved road. The president was brought up here and he arranged for the road. Onwards we go past water buffaloes and waving kids, stopping to regain blood in our behinds and once to fix a fallen chain. The weather says fair, not hot and not raining, after 3 hours and 32KM we are back at base after circling the island. Time for a beer and a sit. We think we make arrangements to get a motorised canoe the next day. Then pop down the road and over the wooden bridge for some snap. On our return we meet an Canadian guy, who is recently married and an expectant farther. Although his wife is currently working on her masters in Chang Mai. He has lived in Laos for seven years and can speak Lao. In fact his wife is Lao.

We wave good bye to Don Khong and head up the Mekong to Don Det. On the boat are also Canadian Sharon and Kiwi Jessica. We pull up on the beach in full sun, try not to fall in the river as we hulk our bags on to our back and go off hostel searching. There are two sides of the island  sunset boulevard and sun rise strip. We have been told that sunset is cooler and as there is limited electricity (and fans) here, we head for the sunset side.

Bear and Sharon head off heroically looking for a suitable bed, Jessica and I guard the bags. They know each other as they have both been teaching together in South Korea. Apparently there's a bunch of cash to be had there, also there's a weird key system for renting a flat. You give the landlord a great lump of cash as deposit and then pay no rent. Any damages comes out of the key money and the landlord invest the money to make a profit out of you living there. Strange! Although Sharon had the surprise that her landlord told her one day that they where going to knock the house down next week.

Bear returns and we find a hut with bathroom (of sorts). It's very basic (read dive), but has piglets near by and a veranda to drink whiskey on. We cycle to the other island Don Khon and look at some much better guest house that we decide not to stay in. Back over the abandon French railway bridge and back to base all worn out by the sun. Although a great day of watching kids playing and saying hello and water buffaloes walling in the river. After a good meal served by a cute Laos girl who Claire wants to steal, the sun sets.

It was a night of bugs and drugs. The drugs being local whiskey and beer. The bugs being every where a vast storm of them, that turned my arm into a Mumbia road for bugs, as I desperately tried to take us out of pitch black by lighting a candle. The bugs then fly around the flame at immense speed often dying in the wax. In the morning the wax bug corpse structure is was enough to turn your stomach.
The lightening every now and again wakes up the sky and we listen to Jessica's flight of the concords ipod music and try to avoid the huge praying mantas in the toilet.

The next day we get cycles again and head down the waterfalls we missed the day before. We watch the waterfalls do there thing for a bit and then follow the curious beach signs. It's a bit like junior kick start challenge: Over tree stumps, through puddles, past rocks.
Then we are there on the sand and a little swimming area near the shore. There are also signs saying people have died here.

After cycling back that night the rain falls like hell, which forces us into the safety of our mossy net in the hut. We have booked the trip to Cambodia's Phnom Penn and away from the land where they use Dutch chickens as currency and have no cushions or even mattresses sometimes....

title: Holiday in Cambodia
description: Up early and check out of bug hut, the sun is rising and we are spending our last Kip on anything to make us feel better. We dump our bags outside of the travel shack and cash in the two dollar IOU note I got yesterday whilst buying the ticket. More people show up and soon we are lugging our stuff down the mud road to the waters edge and on to a motorised canoe. We are about to spend all day with these people, not the best prospects. A pleasent enough sail to the main land and bundle ourselves in to a mini bus, to go get our exit stamp and then our Cambodian visa. It's all hot and slow, plenty of forms to fill in, sweating and photographs. Then we are off into Cambodia with the dead Kennedys song playing in my head.

We stop off again, unload and wait for the big bus to take us to the capital. The bus is terrible and turns up when our cafe food does. The pressure is eased by a bloke from Mexico and his Argentinian friend playing and singing on their acoustic guitars. I appreciate their talent but don't like the songs. The road is mostly paved, everyone's luggage is packed along the isle of the bus and covered with planks of wood that is used as the floor. We have a slight bumpy unpaved dry mud detour but make it back on the road before the rain buckets down and good job too. The tyre underneath the bus did go pop though and it is also placed on the already overcrowded bus. We arrive well into the night and in the fuss of getting off the bus, we forget the Bolivian hat. This is a sad state of affairs as we've had it all along the trip.

It's close to 11pm on a Saturday night, we check a few hostels out, but we are just tired and want a bed. We end up in a place that looks over the lake covered in greenery. A couple are watching Juno and we join in. Swig a beer. We soon find out that anything is available on the menu here: including opiates and all sorts. Two of the staff spend most of the time lying down and throwing up. Ugly, messed up Cambodia. Another of the staff blames 1975 for it, although he was too young to be there for the ugly event himself, he leans on the fact that it's inheritable.

The next day we get our stuff together, past the stoners watching a film and check out. We then check into Simon 2, a much better place where we are able to take our first bath in months, wonderful . It's called Simon 2 after the owners son and even though, the sign depicts a picture of a brown kiwi, he's not from NZ he's from Maastricht. This is all getting too strange. This year is getting on the side of too much for him, 8 years ago there where only 20 backpackers but now there's too many. This used to be the seedy part of town, there were certain alleys you didn't go down but now it's much better. Still there's an advert in every room to go see the killing fields or cock-fight or shoot a machine gun. Hard drugs are offered just out side the door of the hostel and happy pizzas or paranoid pizzas as we call them are available in all restaurants, but everything seems safe and friendly enough. This city doesn't seem so poor, it does have echo's of India, random traffic without so many beeps.

We have a day off and go down the Russian market and buy random stuff. Here from the 100's of stalls, you can get motorcycle parts, food, pirate DVD all under one hot tin roof. The next day we intend to see the genocide stuff at the killing fields and S21 (interrogation house) . As you will not be able to imagine, it's really disturbing stuff. Feels weird taking photographs but it's here to be remembered. With that done we leave the city for the town that has the icon of Cambodia  Siem Reap.

title: Crocs and tentacle trees
description: After a six hour not so painful bus journey, apart from a film that the locals found hilarious which involved a down trodden husband sneering off to the Karaoke barrow only to be found out by his wife to be beaten by a stick, anyway we get to Siem Reap.

We make a pathetic attempt to walk to town in the heat, we decide to take it easy. Two young Irish guys try and do the same as it gets dark but they soon return not too far behind scared away by the local working girls offering the local loving menu when they were not hungry.

Waking up is never easy but we sit for breakfast around noon. It soon becomes apparent that the three blokes opposite a mixture of northerners and Irish are completely wasted and are discussing violence quite loudly. The Irish young man produces a bottle of whisky with a cobra in it and offers it to all in the vicinity. We decide not to take his generous offer. As they all slink off upstairs to continue their session the eldest one makes a beeline for our table. We manage to subdue the situation before the staff lead him away whilst explaining that they had all been up all night.

A day of rest but we get to the local market that feels like a ghost town so we crawl back in the oppressive mid day sun. for our evening meal we eat at Dead Fish. A truly bizarre establishment. It resembles a warehouse with many mezzanine levels, precariously held up by slim lengths of cable with a pulley system that links it to the kitchen and bar. As we browse the menu we gain some insight into this weird place. They have mirrors everywhere for the staff to check their make-up, a number of clocks that all tell the wrong time as they don't want to know, they have ducks to eat all the insects and crocodiles because they tried to build
a crocodile farm but they decided that they actually liked crocodiles so they keep them in a pen at the restaurant, of course.

As I headed to the loo there it was the crocodile pen containing at least four of the not so little monsters. I think that the pen was quite small, although it disappears into the darkness beneath the wooden floorboards, however at least they are safe for the meantime unlike the ducks who seen to have gone from the pond but duck does appear on the menu. Not only duck but pig cheek with skin, pig trotters, cows heart and various stir fried bugs. Yum.
At eight we jump in a tuck tuck and we are flying down the streets towards the legendary Angkor Watt.

Its the largest religious building in the world dedicated to Vishnu. The king apparently picked up a few ideas from the Indian sailors who got stranded in Cambodia waiting for the whether system to change direction. The architecture is outstanding and every square millimetre is covered in intricate carvings.
The main carving depicts the story of gods and demons playing tug of war with a snake until the ocean of milk is churned up until they are able to extract the elixir of immortality.

On to Bayon where the gently smiling faces look down from every possible angle. People report that it feels eerie but I find it strangely cosy. Last but not least we head to Ta Prohm. The jungle was originally cleared to build the hundreds of temples but here the jungle has reclaimed its land and the roots of magnificent old trees have established there roots through every crack in the brickwork and they smother the buildings squeezing them into rubble. Its a truly magical fairytale place, one not so far from a set of Pans Labyrinth. This obviously is my favourite. Power to the trees.

title: Burning waters
description: We splashed out on a taxi to the border as the road is in real bad nick and will be that way for the next two years, as the Cambodians toil in the hot sun to get it widened, repaved and with extra storm drainage. There are rumours that Thai airlines bribe people to make the road bad.

We see the bus we could have got on the way and it looked hot and miserable. The taxi gets to the border in 4 hours, the bus takes 10 hours plus. So by midday we step out the taxi on a dusty traffic island
and queue up to get our exit stamp in the weird messed up casino border town.
Then we walk over the border and fill out more forms to get a new Thai visa. On to the back of a tuk-tuk and away down the duel carriage way holding on to our bags and enjoying the welcome breeze.
The driver takes us to the bus station. No, no, train station!" we explain. Then we reach the train station. I get
harassed by a young monk lad, who Claire recognises has learning
difficulties. The train station doesn't sell tickets until 1pm. We wait.
Then the office opens and we queue fending off the monk as we do. Then I
realise we only have dollars and this will not work as we need Bhart. I
get a bloke to take me on the back of his motorbike to an ATM, get the
cash. Get back and we get our tickets (less than one English pound each) for the 6
hour train trip to Bangkok.

The journey is great. We sit by the window. The conductor routinely clicks his ticket punch whilst walking down the train. We look out on the unfolding scenery. The vibrant green fields, the sea of white water lotus. Plants crawl over the electric lines. Frighten water buffalo charge away from the roar of the train. We pull the metal shutters down as the rain starts to chucking it down. Although this does not last for long and before we know it we are faffing the shutter backup. Kingfishers sit on the lines and herons float by on the heat in the air. Often people come down the train with wicker baskets full of sugar cane and plastic bags full of brown food stuff. By the time we get to Bangkok it's dark and we need a rest. The train does what seems a great deal of stopping before we get to the main station.

Off we get and the monk from the start of the trip spots me and the hassle starts again. I quickly try and dodge through the walking crowd but he's on my case. Luckily I take a quick corner and I loose him, Although I almost loose Claire. We go to the ticket office and secure a train and boat ride to (Ko Tao) turtle island, but it's not for a couple of days. Another bit of price negotiating with speed racer tuk-tuk driver which costs about as much as our last 6 hour train journey and we are off.
I think the train (which was tourist free) forgot to charge us fraang (foreigner) prices.

The guest house we had our eye on is full but we soon find another and then the rain starts. We don't do much the next few days. Avoid the rain, buy sun glasses (my 4th pair), book to read on the beach (Haruki Murakami's After Dark) and swim ware. It was back to the block where you buy egg Pad Thai fried up in front of your eyes for 25 Bhart (62 Bhart to the English pound). All great selection of faked goods, including Ids: Degrees, TEFAL certificates etc. Also a man on the corner folds pop cans into tuk-tuks for 100 Bhart. Claire also gets fish and chips from the English oh my cod café.

Then it's back to the station and getting in to a Thai train bed. Waking up before the crack of dawn to get a bus and boat to the island. The island is great. Still a bit commercial and definitely has a diver's bent but all the same great. A million places to take your PADI course. We head towards the south east of island where it is quieter and there is good snorkelling. We hire cycles, although the heat and the hills restrict our adventures. It rains, a knock on effect from the Philippines storms and the disaster in Burma, not the rainy season yet.

The next day we go on an organised snorkelling lap of the island. A wonderful day. Sail up to a cover jump in and look at the fishes (Claire saw two sharks) and then climb back on the boat, have a coffee, some fruit, then off to the next place. We stopped off at around five different spots and it was great.

Although it was a little cloudy the bright fish and coral where amazing to explore. We need to get some sort of chart to work out what we saw, but there where parrot fish and gangs of fish of all different verities that seem to go from coral to coral munch stuff up there. You hear them chomping away. I mastered the diving with a snorkel trick.

The problem was the sun though. It didn't feel hot. Yes. I got 1st degree (sun) burns (A Parisian anaesthetist told me in a cool pool bar the day after the day after). So Claire breaks out the natural yoghurt and our local Israeli/south African/English bar manager gives us some fresh aloe Vera. This all gets smeared on my back and I lay still for a very long time. Claire not to be out done fell down some concrete steps in the dark and ripped her knee up a bit.

So the next couple of days I tried not to moan and we concentrate on planning the full moon party coming up. This happens on the 20th on the very commercial main island, so we have decided to get a boat over that will return us at 7am or something daft like that, so I hope it's good....

title: Luna Tike's
description: It was the day before and we where running around. Well more like limping around getting supplies  Whiskey, wakey (some sort of energy drink), small sunscreen and insect repellent. Then we jump in the back of a pick up and head to the harbour. It was very apparent which boat was ours, it was the one with the bad music blasting out and excited young people. We brace ourselves and ignore the whispers of regret. From pier across boat we scramble on to the party boat. As we step foot on the boat we are handed a beer. They don't look a bad crowd all lounging around sipping there beers and trying to chat above the thump of the music. The boat fills up and there is a good feeling on the boat, one of the crew tries his best at dancing  and is all smiles as he sips on his own beer.  Then we are off under a beautiful sky as the world twists away from the sun for another day. Drinking continues and there only a handful of over excited people. Only the crew can walk around causally picking up bottles as most people find it hard to walk around with out lurching to grab hold of something or someone to stop there fall as the boat rocks its way towards the next island.

The sky turns dark. It's going to rain. The atmosphere is wonderful and a stark contrast to the brightly coloured party people and then it rains. Chucks it down, everyone heads under the deck roof to stay dry. Everyone apart from an accent-less long haired bearded lad from Manchester. Who just stood there for a while before he decide it as getting too much and joined us. He looked like a good bloke to talk to and as our whisky loosend our social bones we started talking. He had just won 9 Grand using his dad's internet on line poker account. After collage and feeling loney not doing much at home, he got a manual job, but jacked it in after the gambling started to become an income and now he was here, spending his winnings.

We also met a French bloke and his Polish girlfriend. He worked for the oil industry. Most of the time he was isolated in an island above Japan, although I think it was Russian owned. He thought we had reached peek oil, I never doubted Max Kieser.
