The boat arrived and we had a few muffled instructions and we where clambering off the boat in the dark over another boat and on to the pier. Then we where hit by a get on the island for full moon party tax. This was in the form of a blue  wrist band which we never put on. Next up was food. We hadn't eaten since breakfast. We found a hectic falafel restaurant and dug in. The table next to us was full of people covering themselves baddly in UV paint and acting randomly.

It was around 9pm. After our fill we headed down the streets which where packed with stalls selling buckets of booze and energy drinks. It had the atmosphere of American spring break rather than any Pagan tropical island secret. Hard sell excess not hedonistic and random, more macho and regulated.

We hit the beach and there is a fair few people up and down, with huge sound systems pumping out bad dance music. A huge flaming skipping rope outside one beach lined super bar. A huge crowd is gathered round as the flames lick around the twirling rope. Drunk youths try to keep up their rhythmic jumps before they get burnt and disappear back into the crowd. To a starch contrast on the beach are the wonderfully graceful Chinese lanterns. These are lit and held until they reach critical mass and wonder off into the night sky and out to sea.

The over consumption continues, quiet hellish as reflected in the glowing horns you can buy but not the glowing round glasses. We head down the beach to the bar at the end for a drink, a sit and most importantly the use of their toilet. The toilet has two Spanish blokes outside singing Johnny Cash and the ubiquitous gecko chirping. We are joined at our table by two English Lads. One works for Lloyd's of London and is blown away by the successes of his sister in the drum and bass scene. The other works in a tower block full of magazines, a stereotype on every floor he tells us and has a sharp mind for films. Good chats, but we can't hang around we want to dissect the messiness on the beach.

People are now cutting out the middle pipe and pissing directly into the sea. Thai police are on the prowl looking for a pay day. I saw them shake one man down but he had nothing they could turn into a bribe so they let him go. We drank and I started random rants with a few other beach dwellers and the night blurred on and out of memory. I remember us dancing ourselves into a hole on the sand and slowly noticing more and more people sleeping on the beach.

The heavy ache of tiredness starts to pull us down. Slowly nonsense conversations with stranger x lose their pace. Then the earth spins around and the sun appears to rise giving a calming change of mood and boost of energy. People wake up on the beach and run around taking photos in the warm light of day break.

Before we know it we are back in the 7-11 getting more booze for the morning boat back.  We wonder back on the boat and everyone is falling asleep. We sit around consider who is the most graceful sleeper and soon get chatting to a young lad from Johannesburg about economics and politics. Claire spots some bloke talking to himself and goes over to assist. I soon join her and he seems OK, but he's not really. His nails are all long as his hair and he wares a Muslim skull cap. He's a Serbian Canadian. Although we have some great conversations, we see him a few days later quickly walking down the street ranting to himself.

We get back to our island and a taxi home with some other very sleepy party goers. 11am and we hit the sack. The next day we hear of Grace's arrival (Bear's friend has just had a baby!) and Mick starts a sober month of recovery.

title: Leaving and Arriving
description: So the next couple of days just where a dozy case of waiting for the boat. We bought some a snorkel and Bear tried it out in Shark bay.  I remember on our last day at dusk watching the family which ran our hostel take their radio control boats out on the sea. The children looked on, the parents laughed and the dogs barked at them. A fitting farewell to our beach.

Then we find ourselves sat in an internet café eating and chatting to folk on Skype. The boat was not until 10, then it slipped to 11pm. It was all dark down the harbour with the odd bright light watching heavy machinery. The ship with the JCB unloading gravel turned out to be our cruise liner. The time came, tickets where exchanged and a sailor nimbly balanced both our rucksacks on either side of him and walked along the tight rope like metal alley on the side of the cargo bay and to the cabins at the rear of the ship. He beckoned us to follow and we did with only his smile gleaming in the light. We didn't fall into the black drink we made it to the cabin.

The boat we booked was definitely a working boat with grit and oil and an industrial I framed riveted dark room. That is put aside for a few make shift beds for tourists who had been suckered into being cargo.

Bear and I laughed it off, where as four young English women where feeling a little insecure to be stuck in a grim box with a handful of friendly sailors. We clicked a fan on and the metal heat dissipated. After heavy grinding and shifting of dirt by a JCB, more tourist arrived all wide eyed and confused, then we set sail. Slowly. After a blurry read we fall asleep. Unfortunately I was next to Bruce lee who kicked me through out the night.

The dawn came and so did the shore. Back on dry land we where loaded into a mini bus not unlike the one we had in NZ. Some people where bound for Bangkok and some for Hat Yai. Both in different directions. Sometimes its best to sit tight.

Before we knew it we where sat with a bloke from Bradford eating breakfast and waiting for our connection bus to Hat Yai. Post Human Geography degree and crappy factory jobs he was now a traveller. He had many a tail of drinking and ending back at his hostel early in the morning. He told of loosing flip flops and stealing others. He had friends all over the world he was visiting. He taken favours from them all. He paid no rent to his folks and he used to like indie rock  Kings of Leon, White Stripes, Libertines  etc. etc., but now a days he was out of touch. He said he found it hard to go home and it took him a while to stop living out of a rucksack when he got back.

Then we were off to another place, a bus station and our bus turned up and we where off. Although there seemed to be no tourists on the bus, when we got off five hours later the tuk-tuk touts where at our throats. We decide to all jump in one and head towards our chosen hostel near the train station.

This place is horrid, full of porn DVD for sale on the street and just like a rebuilt bombed city. It was a high rise border town with a lot of dark corners. Our room was basic at best, we got a film and watched it. Howard, the man from Bradford was off to the west cost of Malaysia we parted as we where heading east.

Now British Rail is criminally bad and it just shows when we get our ticket to head towards the border further south, the Sungai Kolok crossing. It cost just over an English pound for this four hour journey! Once again don't take the tourist touted buses at around 500% more, stick with the locals it's better for so many different reasons. But first the problem is breakfast, which Bear finds in the shape of fruit. Ananas and Mango.

The train pulls up and seems fairly full, although it seems a lot of people are getting off. They are getting off with their wears, which consist of huge plastic bags full of chilli's and other foods, as well as hand bags and other sell-able's.

So we board the train and sit in a carriage that has green seats opposite each other like a wide tube train. There is no plastic on this train though, it is all chrome and painted brown wood. There are some small posters advertising chilli hot sauce. A series of fans on the ceiling that gather cob webs, although the carriage is not hot.

Not another backpacker in sight. A man with a large M16 machine gun gets on and walks slowly down the centre of the carriage, we just munch our fruit. The carriage is full of a cross section of ages. Old men staring wistfully out of the window, kids playing with their mobiles and an old women push coal or it that shit down the carriage in a basket. She smiles at Bear and often shakes her hand and cackles.

The ticket punchers soon come down, clicking their punches. One growls at the old women as she is putting the coal stuff out on paper at the end of the carriage. She just smacks him around the ankles and growls back.

Outside the window the sky has a few fair weather clouds and the countryside is lush and alive with butterflies. We pass the odd red dust road and every station has sandbags and heavy army machinery from an almost forgotten disagreement with Malaysia. Also as we get closer to the border, in fact I think Yala is the the point where change becomes obvious, everything is going slightly Muslim. More and more hooded women and men in skull caps with long skirts. Although I do spot one kid who has misfit slip on shoes.

The carriage fills up, people are now standing in every space. Hunger catches up and we stop one of the hawkers who work their way up and down tapping there rings on a tray full of different foods. 20 Bhart later and we have our teeth in a boiled corn on the cob each. Yum. We don't follow the tradition of throwing plastic rubbish out the window and sit tight until we arrive.

We get to the last stop and pile off the train on the track, a quick toilet stop as the sky gets angry. After asking a few soldiers on the station where the border is we head across the track towards where we think the border might be. Then it rains, full on tropical storm rains. Dripping we make it to the Thailand exit stamp border and then on to Malaysia. Everyone else seems to be in vehicles and we just splash by the side of the road to the walkers entrance. We are alone and it seems closed as first but it isn't and we pass into the country.

The rain is still hammering down. Then we are approached by a taxi driver offering a lift to the bay where we can get a boat to the islands. This obviously is a well travelled route and he guesses right first time where we want to go. We are too wet to bother about haggling and just ask him to take us to an ATM so we can get some local money. He then picks up a yank and a Canadian and the price drops.
The yank has scabs all over his face and both of them seem very well travelled in party destinations around the world. The yank complains about Muslim countries and we drive on.

I don't know if it's the paxo theory or the fact that the driver wants to get to town to pray, but he drives like an extreme mumbia nutter. The paxo theory being that when Paxo was straight edge (no drink etc, not unlike Muslims) he used to drive in an extreme crazy fashion.

We get there a bit stiff, sleepy and hungry. We are sold a boat trip for the morrow and we check into a crap hotel. There is an arrow on the ceiling of the room, I wonder if this is Mecca's direction, as we see on the next few rooms we stay in. The bathroom door cannot open more than a ¼ due to the sink and the whole town has the charm of a truckers stop. The plugs are UK plugs though. We have some crap food from a place on the corner and hit the sack.

The next day we are ushered down the road with some Chinese girls towards a jetty full of tourists. Chaos. We sling our bags on a small 12 seater speed boat and we are away, wind in our hair and smiles on our faces. The sun bounces off the sea. The head of the boat bobs up and down as we cut through the water. Dropping off people as we go, we are amazed how clear the water is and how much life we can see below.

We get to long beach on the small island and have to get another water taxi to the shore. After wondering around the beach for a bit, we find accommodation that is not like a tenko corrugated iron heat trap. Although as we find out after the next few days it is a heat trap and has a loud generator that kicks in from 6:30pm to 9am, which is the only time you can use the very necessary fan.

This place is alive. Little grass hoppers dance around the grass as you walk and often you come across timid huge monitor lizards. There are also eagle type birds on the beach and circling above. The jungle surrounds the beach and there is a little 10 minute track through it to a beach on the other cost. It's hot!

Most of the beach stalls do not sell booze, although there are two raga bars that do. We spend the next few days in a bit of a heat blur, until we find some much better accommodation with 24 electricity on the other quieter coral beach. Also you can snorkel and see fishes on this beach. We do have our first Malay food in the shape of a curry. It is great, although we had to have a harvest of flavoursome pods and sticks hidden in the food before you could spoon it down. Also they do a great chocolate milk shake, almost everywhere on the island. The chocolate ice cream towered over the glass, so to stop a tsunami of melted shake I spooned it down fast. this caused an ice cream headache of extreme short lived pain. Karl reckons he's immune to this and has never experienced this pain, not that I would wish this on anyone, a cruel side of me would like him put to the test on this misfortune.

title: Fishland
description: We quickly adjust to the wonderful new room with its constant fan, hot water,flushing toilet all mixed together with contented sighing of a sea view. This bay also allows you to swim and snorkel without the constant worry of being decapitated by one of the local speed boats. So we happily head into the water on the first day and find an array of multi coloured fish nibbling the mushroom shaped coral around us but ouach, eeec tiny little electric shocks like itching powder all over your body. I was a tad freaked out, we later find the little critters are Sea Lice. Microscopic nipping creatures. We book a snorkeling tour for the next day anyhow.

Eight people are loaded into a tiny boat but all equipped and Mick's delicate skin covered by a T shirt we head to Shark Bay. The guide tells us to follow him and soon he is shouting shark shark we swim after him as quick as our little flippers would carry us and there it is a Black Tipped Reef

Shark circling below us. They are roughly a meter and a half long and look very well fed (luckily). The next stop is a long stretch of turquoise water in search of Giant Turtles. We spot five in all. They are the most beautiful graceful creatures I have ever encountered, they seem to exudes an air of wisdom and knowing. We hover over taking in the scene and then it starts to rise from the sea bed to take in a gulp of air. It swims about a meter in front of us and we glide along with it. The approximate size of the largest turtle was about over a meter long and about a meter wide. We get so close that we see the dual cleaner fish living underneath the turtles tummy. I'm glad he has some company as they seem such lonely creatures. Amazing experience. On to Coral Garden as we jump into the water we are already surrounded by hundreds of fish of all colours shapes and sizes.

Then on to romantic beach where the sun was streaming through the jack-in-a-box clouds, this in turn made tunnels of light underwater. We get to see a small sting ray, more nemo fish hiding in the sea anemone and smogs of collective thinking little fish. Even a baby octopus and pikey fish swimming near the surface. As the day dies the sea come alive and every so often a whole school of fish arc out of the water.

After we get back on dry land we shower and go for dinner. The sun has set and we are sat at the beach fish BBQ restaurant with the NYC waiter. The light house winks at us from across the bay as we fill up on Malay delights.
Then its back to the cabin to watch the bats bombing through our porch, as well as - heady and headaleena, two geckos on our door.

The next two days are spent snorkelling independently from the beach. We realise the later it gets the more the wildlife comes out to play. At sunset I spot a large black reef shark swimming toward me in the shallows but he soon spots me and shoots off. On our last day we go in search of turtles and we aren't disappointed as Mick and I have an exclusive meeting with Mr Turtle. A wonderful gift for our final day.
>Pictures are stolen from internet land, but we saw these and more
(as usual click on the picture to make them bigger)

title: Raining tea and strawberries
description: We woke in the highest cabin, the noisy French family had gone and we where soon to follow their led. We crowbarred ourselves out of bed and looked out through the trees past the twirling squirrels and down on to the bay for the last time.

Soon we where plodding along the jetty with our bags. The third boat was ours and off we went after almost falling in the drink and standing on tutting muslin mother's feet. Back on the main land we waited for our mini bus to the highlands. We met an young Irish couple  George and Teresa. One studying disease, the other to study civil engineering. It's funny it's due to them that I'm typing this in this gloomy room in Kuala Lumpur.

We pile on to the mini bus and we are away. Later I find myself trying to tell a Malaysian man all that I knew about Guernsey whilst waiting for a toilet in the change over stop. His brother in law lives there and all I could say was potatoes.

The next bus was a taxi Cameron highland bound, well Tanah Rata bound, well fathers guest house bound, well Cameron Secrets really. You see an English priest used to own this, 1920's build hostel, but he past away last year and now it might be called Cameron Secrets.

Anyway after passing 10's of logging trucks carrying very old trees, through NZ type landscape, watching the drivers son's head jerk back up from sleep a hundred times and the looping tape attacking our ears with Malay iron maiden and rock ballads, we arrive. The weather is cool at 1300 to 1829 meters above the sea. This is the place of the (never over) land rover, there are thousands of them here in various states of repair. It's weirdly English, in a story book sense. Convent on the hill, cream teas, even a farther and son playing badminton. Chinese, Indian and Malay descent people. Great food and rainy weather. The hostel is like a rehab centre for sun burnt travellers.

Strawberries , strawberries, strawberries every bloody where. It seems that the British as well as giving the locals the lovely lovely tea they also left there love of tat You cant buy anything here without a strawberry on it and all the cars strawberry have seat covers etc. Having resisted the urge to buy a strawberry umbrella, socks and bag we decide to do a jungle walk and visit the tea plantation.

About 14 people get crushed into the back of a land rover with an overexcited although very knowledgeable tour guide. We snake our way through the rolling mountains to a breathtaking view of the ocean of tea in front of me. All that lovely beautiful tea, I felt all guide and warm inside. YUM but for now not a drop to drink.

The guide tells us lots of fascinating tea facts like that black, white and green tea are all from the same bush. Crammed back into the Land rover we head off until the Land rovers battery dies so the walk is longer than expected. The whole jungle is covered in moss, the key to the local eco system. The guide points out plants with medicinal purposes such as citronella leaf, A plant to reduce pain from leach bites and another that reduces cholesterol. Finally we get to the Tea plantation where we get a whirlwind tour and yes yes finally a beautiful, wonderful large mug of tea. Bliss.

We get dropped off at the Butterfly Farm which was a bit run down and grim to say the least. You see there was a load of cattle farms here, but they contracted a disease, so they got killed and replaced with cactus, butterfly, roses, honey farms.
The capturers all cooped up in there all looked
a tad sad but we couldn't help but take
a few picks of the happier looking critters. With no local bus or taxi in sight we start to hike back in the rain. An hour and
a half later with no sign of the guest house we give in when we finally spot a taxi. Good job as well as that's when the hills started.

The next day we toddle off to Robinson Fall, as my sir name is Robinson I feel the ancestral pull to go and visit, however this Robinson did fall down a huge bloody drain on the way. That night we went to the centre to see a Chinese parade. It was an hour late and then it really really rained. It was very underwhelming seeing a load of soggy floats and blokes weaving a fireless dragon in plastic bag up and down in the rain.
One more night at Fathers and we find a moth nearly as big as my hand in the corridor, then we were up bright and early to catch out super VIP bus to Kuala Lumper.
- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -

title: Bear will be blood
description: The last blog was posted on the blog's birthday, at writing this we have less than two weeks before our flight tickets run out and we find ourselves scratching our heads in Nottingham. Anyhow, by the time we reach Kuala Lumper the temperature has already risen back to its usual sweat. We get dropped off in the middle of the city after a bit of a taxi faff we get to our recommended hostel in the golden triangle. It's a bit gloomy but we soon find out it's quiet cheap and roomy compared to the others around.

The next couple of days consist of sight seeing and running around the hectic China town. As well as eating curry climbing the Menara tower to look at the Petronas towers (2nd biggest sky scraper in the world) and visiting the Islamic museum - an amazing building with an Islamic women are not oppressed honestly exhibition. All good, all hot, then we flew.

We land at KK in Sabah, Malaysian Borneo. We check in to the hotel Simon has booked for us and go out for food. After a quick call to Simon we go to Upperstar bar. Simon pulls up on his bike and we chat the night away.
We laze the next few days away until we are driving to the

Nature Lodge at Kinabatangan with Simon, Ed and Naz. They are heading to a bat cave to rig up some platforms for some BBC filming. Bear and I are heading for leach central. The drive takes about six hours and the landscape on the way in incredable.We have a couple of beers with Simon and share a few nottingham and Jungle tails. Apprehensively we retire to our hut a little concerned about the creatures that might be keeping us company in the dark. But only
a frog joins us.

Soon it was get your wellies on we are going for a tramp in the jungle. First check your socks are over your trousers and off we march and your clothes are tucked in (anti leech stylee). The wellies come in handy as the mud often reaches the top of them or in Claire case knee height.. We do get to witness the man of the jungle hanging hairy in the trees , an adult male complete with his plate face. We feel fairly good about this as it's quiet rare to see an orangutan in the wild. We make our way to the fish full oxbow lake.

This is all done with short stops in between to check for leaches. We all fall fowl of them, although we get them off before they start drinking. They tend to hang around the edges of leafs trying to smell out your warmth (see film). After they get on you, they sort of climb to any crevasse on your body that is warm. If you catch them climbing you can just flick them off, otherwise a spray of bug repellent will make them curl up and then you just flick them off. They will drink for around 20 minutes and drop off leaving you to bleed everywhere but not in any danger. Quiet horrid really, but after the initial fear it's easier to cope with.

However when we get back to our hut we find one under bear's arm pit that has been having a good sup. We get rid of him but the blood flows. The sweetly singing women at the lodge help out patching the hole up and put tobacco on the wound, which we are very dubious of. That night we get to see a water leach in a bottle which are more the big black slug like thing that I expected. Yuk. We get a great talk by Papa bear (the owner of the lodge). We learn about the wild life, locals, logging, palm oil as we down a beer or two.
Next was a night river cruise where saw more orangutans, black squirrels and proboscis monkeys. Lack of big lens on the camera left us with few photos.

After a kip it's back on the boat and bus heading to Sepilok. We spend two nights there. It has a world class rainforest discovery centre that has canopy walks and more information than we can remember  they should really publish a book. Also we go to the orangutan rehab centre, where we watch a orangutan feed and the cheeky monkeys eat the scraps. Before we know it Simon has picked us up again and we are KK bound eating snake skinned fruit with Ed and Naz. Back past the palm trees stretching out as far as the eye can see where once stood a rainforest.
Our exit is all a bit of a rush. We get to meet Simon's wife Christine and two week old son Ewan, Louise was still at nursery again. Before bombing off to the airport.

We see more of Sabah by the air. The turquoise lined island disappear as does the mountain that is cut in two by a line of cloud. We see the sky darken and the orange full moon turns white as we cross the equator Bali bound. It
looked like we were going to fall into the sea, like a bright eyes song, but we just sneak on to the tight run way to the city of ageing surfers carving out the left handers.
The Borneo experience was all to brief but thanks to Simon we were able to make the most of it. Cheers to the Amos clan.

title: Hindude Surf Glut
description: What did we do in Kuta? I dunno, ended up with some pricey trousers and a feeling of Indian hassle. The skies where dotted with kites. We saw traditional dancing and eat a great meal on the solstice. Bear did help some Java school girls with their English lessons. This was in the shade of trees on the beach where some good surfing was happening. We didn't get knocked over by some surf board carrying moped Aussie. We
did leave for Ubud. But first a quick motorcycle ride with luggage through the back streets to a road that would take a bus.
An hour or so later and we where at the small bus station. After getting our orientation we headed for monkey forest road. Heavy bags and hot sun didn't break a great first impression.

A tout promising swimming pool hostel leads us to ?Sagittarius Inn and Bungalows, just off monkey forest road and wow. A small army where brushing the lawn clean. A truly great place. The restaurant associated with the hotel is of a similar quality. In this fine establishment Bear tastes the best spring rolls of her life.
Although the paths of this town are drainage covers that go up and down, the shops and massage parlours make for a good browse. Although saying no to touts is wearing.
We spend a day in the monkey forest where tourist are climbed on by monkeys and men prepare structures for the cremation ceremony.

We enrol on a cookery course that takes us to the colourful food market in the morning and to the peaceful rice paddies for outside cooking with Nanny and her daughter. By mid day we've cooked and eaten more than our fill, with a glass of wine we contently fall asleep in the hostel.
Ubud holds us. We go to near by markets and just drift through the days jumping in the pool when it gets too hot.
Tonight is more traditional chanting and tomorrow we prepare for Hong Hong.
- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -

title: Stir fried stumble
description: Well the chanting and running around on burning coconut husks was worth a watch. A hundred blokes chanting around a fire. Any hows we get the bus out of town and on to Hong Kong. It's big, dotted with water, green hills and sky scrapes, shipping containers and shops and shop and more shops. We play hotel shuffle, eat local noodles and have a pint at Stanley. Stanley has a beach and a market and a sea front surrounded by lush green hills. It's a tube and a bus away from where we are staying but it's easy enough to get to. At night we watch the sky scrapers do their nightly light show.

Then we wake and head to the huge airport. After we check in we have to get a tube train to our gate. Soon I'm drinking wine on the 12 hour trip back to London. We arrive before we leave and the dirty dysfunction of London airport tube transport throws us towards Victoria bus station for a pint and a lift back to Nottingham. Midnight we get to Cherry trees and a wonderful warm welcome. The next night we are down the peacock to a lovely friendly gathering wondering what has happened. We feel like we have been rolled around in waves thrown into a time washing machine and spat out the other side... AAAARRRRRR SSSPPPLLLAAAT.

We hope Nottingham will be kind..... Ultimately I'm sure it wont. There is so much more I want to se e. Norwegian frozen waterfalls, Romanian and Canadian bears, St Petersburg, hot hungry springs, Canadian Rockies, Californian red woods, Tibet, Darjeeling, Central America, African and Mongolian planes. Brazil. North Scotland, the forest of dean, Hadrian's wall, the Pennine way. Ireland. The list goes on. In these times it looks like you will need an ever expanding bag of time and money to do this. The grey skies here don't effect how good it feels to see friends and family. We have a fist full of weddings to go to and whole bunch of new babies to meet. So maybe we can trick ourselves away from the rabbit in the head light feelings. Trying not to thinks of houses, income, form fillings, moving stuff around, phone calls etc etc until Monday. Erm, I wonder how much the flights are to France....
- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -
-(some old films... more to come... maybe)-

title: Rainy return....
description: If you only have one egg how can you not put in one basket, otherwise its omelette everywhere. Within a day of returning I've got a council tax bill. Just plain evil. This started a frenzy to get my house rented out. With the help of the mighty Johnny, heather and Lee this is all happening. Also we've had a welcome back night down the peacock, where we realised booze can help with jet lag.

It's grey here, recession is around the corner no matter if you live Bradford or Bingley, Shotingham or stabtown. Our cash will be in gold our wheels will keep turning. Although need to find somewhere to live and work... erm....
- Thanks for the picture mum -

title: Eat your way out of this one
description: It's hard to hold when the world is spinning. We have a list of very important things that is towering, wavering and shadowing above us. Yes we are making mistakes - like Indian Cookery we attempted to reproduce from our Lesson in India. Not as good as the Carlton Tandoori that we all eat on Saturday night or the Jipack we had on Friday. Also emptied the fridge full of lettuce from my bro and made rocket and potato soup and it worked! Went to the "Nottingham's Culinary traditions" at the central Library on Saturday and got locked in. Sunday we went through the recovery motions. This week is just as packed. Moving, sorting, meeting, sitting...

title: Struggle
description: Devil has not caught us up yet. We are a drift in a sea of forms, arrangements, phone calls and booze. It soon came apparent that it would better to sit by the pool in France now rather than latter. As Claire has to have police checks and I have to wait so see how a man about a boat. In the mean time, we have waves of stress and annoyances. I'm off into town tonight though, to see the butthole surfers and we are on a plane to France tomorrow. We will be returning for my cousins wedding and camping. Oh I had a birthday! It was very good....
- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -

title: Much too much
description: We've just fallen out of a whirl wind. This included watching French line dance at a swimming pool bbq, French beer, cooking, the super lamb bananas of Liverpool, Klimt exhibition, a wedding near Sefton park, a flying saucer on the national express, camping at Birchover for a 4th and 40th birthday and a slow collapse into a coma.... I'm starting to run out of procrastinations....
- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -

title: Quick, quick, slow
description: Still nothing seems to have settled. Although I do seem to be spending time doing very important stuff whilst listening to  and reading  book. We went to the dogs and got drunk for Jimmy's 60th and a whole array of Claire's face-it friends. The next day was the day of watching wire... all day. Had a jipack reunions with back from the dead , Inca cola t-shirt climber, about to take Rollins around Europe bro and an abscess hell absence. Claire saw brand new friends.

title: Skidding in the needles
description: A week of 25% failure and a discovery of countryside and lame VW festival. After which a play on the park with Evie and tidy of an empty house. Also had a long over due meet up with Jase in a butchers that is now a vegetarian café (Dotty's, Mansfield Road) where Charles Bukowski and Vincent Galo are one the wall.
-- (as usual click on the picture to make them bigger) -
In the needles:  Molly Mess:

title: Wedding, self selling, chickens & failure
description: Dranking, drunking and jumping all happend at Rackers Wedding. Then a slow day of recovering and missing pro-palestine drumming party. Then we hobbled off to the house of micky and blue where we are to stay whilst the newly wed are in the med. There are chickens here that give us eggs. Then I got messed around a lot, but eventually got the chance to mess up a meeting, which I did. This led us to dusting off a few bottles of forgotten brew.

title: Naturcide
description: Sorry no pictures of chickens, but there are three of them and they give us eggs daily. The chickens over the fence however are one less due to Blue or Killer getting it in her jaws and snuffing out it's life. Then dumping it in her basket. Erm... This was the Sunday morning after a night drinking with Mr Paxman, whom we picked up from sunnysop on Saturday. This was a welcome change form application form blues. We had other breaks, like visiting Chesterfield Allotments and learning of salvage drivers of my lineage.
Also took Johnny and Evie to the Jipack and a visit from Rachel and Dave. Lots of walking, cooking and stuff.

title: Fall
description: Away from the farm and into a spin of parties, Coventry stress and walking. We built ourselves a good defence and avoided hell. I've been munching my way through time, discussing card games, people-less films. Week 13 has prospects and the leaves are turning and falling and so is the west.

title: Slide...
description: Birthday Sunday, food at kettles and a week of rain and fiery trees, nothing much else really...Might have some gold soon...

title: Building
description: A week of the past and future bleeding into each other. I stepped up to undersell my time for a potential great place to build something useful. It worked and we suddenly became time aware: My free time is about to have some major amputations. As the shot economic news grindes down, the weather turns bright, warm and crisp, letting us have a great walk and deer spotting day.

title: Descent
description: Ok, things have changed. Things are moving. Getting brighter. Next week I should be bringing  back. We went to look at Newstead village, but its grim, isolated and crumbling and no doubt wasn't there when Bryon and Shelly were off their heads in the Abbey.

title: Fancy
description: A week of everyone getting sick, bad letters and the usual. The podcast has been recorded partly in the pub, partly in the old house. However the laptop is giving me pain to edit it. Its getting old. As are other people which manifested itself as an underwater themed boozy dance. A good laugh a slow sunday.

title: Bad transport
description: Its been a week of bad transport. Yes trains don't stop at certain places due to the vicious autumn leaves, which are bright this year due to a wet summer and not my absent eyes. Also trams break down and shuttle buses get full. Any how its the first wage to hit my account in a while and I turned into a coat, a bed and a curry. The curry hailed from  and here are name in Bangla..

title: Bang
description: A fox in the dark. American change, bloody poppies and bangs in the sky. The bed arrived and now we find it hard to leave it.

title: Explode
description: Well not really explode, but a lot happend this week. First there was the gig at the social where D almost lost a tooth. Then there was Chris's party. There was a bear interview and a millon pound thing on antiques roadshow. Will there be a run on the pound? Will the world reject the dollar?

title: Fat week
description: This week I started off learning CPR, Bear got a job, danced at
A 40th birthday party, didn't get a phone and the usual stuff. It got cold. Listen to the hold steady and didn't munch...

title: Searching
description: Week started off with a cartoon at Broadway that gave us an insight into the lebanon massacre, The on to a great curry around johnny's and then a struggle through until pay day. When it arrived it was a shabby anticlimax but I drank it down with another meet up in the peacock again.Then the fog came down and we went back to wollybob park to see deer spot and walk. Sunday we searched for some other place to live.

description: Week started off with a cartoon at Broadway that gave us an insight into the lebanon massacre, Then on to a great curry around johnny's and then a struggle through until pay day. When it arrived it was a shabby anticlimax but I drank it down with another meet up in the peacock again. Then the fog came down and we went back to wollybob park to deer spot and walk. title: Trillions deep
description: The week started off with snow in the first light of day. Soon melted away as the day grew stronger. The next day's night had explosions as a textile factory burnt to the ground. This was followed by the crying city foxes at 3am. The windows replaced just in time for the frost. More food and ambergate walks, bad electrics and horrid gas bills.

title: Steady
description: The week starts off with The Hold Steady. They where great. The rest of the week is the usual work blur and Saturday is a night of film (the avarage inkheart), Balti house curry (great) for Paxo's birthday and a cover version band gig. Sunday is a walk in radcliffe on trent

title: Into the 40's
description: It's hard to know what happened for certain. What I do know is Johnny turned 40 and we eat, family and all, before hand. It's xmas eve and excess has over taken everything else. Also its three years since I lost my passport and a wonderful adventure

title: Too much is never enough
description: 3rd anniversary, Xmas and too much food, too many drinks. Breakdowns and games will all blur away as the cold creeps in and the days get longer....
